p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Mr VASTA (Bonner) (10:01): On behalf of the Chair of the Petitions Committee, I present the 18th report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracey Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP
This committee is supported by staff of the Department of the House of Representatives

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 18 October 2023 and 15 November 2023.
1. The committee resolved to present the following 47 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

p.span: From 10 petitioners—regarding additional supply of international flights in the Australian market (EN5453)
From 109 petitioners—requesting the addition of VISANNE(R) to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) for endometriosis treatment (EN5454)
From 7 petitioners—requesting increased funding to the Assistance for Isolated Children Scheme (EN5455)
From 27 petitioners—requesting the implementation of an enforceable airline passenger compensation scheme (EN5456)
From 11 petitioners—regarding processing times for Subclass 189 Skilled Independent visa and Subclass 190 Skilled Nominated visa (EN5459)
From 7 petitioners—requesting legislation to prevent the sale of energy drinks to consumers under 18 years of age (EN5461)
From 20 petitioners—regarding the release of radioactive wastewater from the Fukushima nuclear plant (EN5462)
From 33 petitioners—regarding the release of radioactive wastewater from the Fukushima nuclear plant (EN5463)
From 269 petitioners—regarding Medicare-subsidised mental health sessions (EN5465)
From 11 petitioners—regarding the processing of Permanent Residency Visa (190) applications from 2021 and earlier (EN5466)
From 527 petitioners—requesting the implementation of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs Defence and Trade's recommendations from its inquiry on human rights violations in Iran (EN5467)
From 51 petitioners—requesting the introduction of an extension provision in appealing matters to the Veterans' Review Board (EN5468)
From 20 petitioners—requesting a parliamentary inquiry into geoengineering (EN5472)
From 34 petitioners—requesting an extension to the Paid Parental Leave scheme from 20 paid weeks to one year (EN5473)
From 29 petitioners—requesting the removal of relationship status in eligibility considerations for Centrelink payments (EN5477)
From 16 petitioners—requesting legislation to prevent online service providers from auto-rebilling inactive accounts (EN5478)
From 17 petitioners—regarding the federal budget for Indigenous affairs (EN5481)
From 32 petitioners—regarding improvements to travel accessibility for immigrants (EN5483)
From 39 petitioners—requesting a public inquiry into the federal and state government response to the COVID-19 pandemic (EN5484)

From 17 petitioners—regarding retailers driving up the cost of groceries without adequately compensating producers (EN5495)
From 8 petitioners—requesting the continuation of the live export industry (EN5496)
From 2 petitioners—regarding the processing of Subclass 190 Skilled Nominated visa applications (EN5497)

From 481 petitioners—requesting the Australian Government to meet with Iran's exiled Crown Prince, Reza Pahlavi (EN5506)

From 239 petitioners—requesting additional funding for Medicare rebates to allow General Practitioners to bulk bill everyone (EN5528)

From 26 petitioners—requesting that the Australian Government no longer resettle refugees in Australia (EN5536)
From 35 petitioners—requesting that Qatar Airways be granted additional international flights in and out of Australia (EN5537)
From 15 petitioners—regarding legislation to progress the development of fusion nuclear technology in Australia (EN5544)
From 60 petitioners—regarding processing delays for Subclass 190 Skilled Nominated visa applications (EN5545)
From 259 petitioners—regarding the processing times of Subclass 309 Partner (Provisional) visa applications in the Amman Embassy (EN5547)
From 8 petitioners—regarding cultural support in the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander participants (EN5549)
From 17 petitioners—requesting standards and education for medical practitioners to support their patients to apply for the NDIS (EN5550)
From 47 petitioners—regarding the outcome of the 2023 Australian Indigenous Voice referendum (EN5551)
From 7 petitioners—requesting the establishment of a program to implement the provision of facilities for remote Indigenous communities (EN5555)
From 190 petitioners—requesting that the tax rate for big corporations and high-earning individuals be raised (EN5557)
From 24 petitioners—requesting stricter deportation laws in Australia (EN5560)
From 3085 petitioners—requesting an amendment to the standing orders to replace daily prayers in the parliament (EN5562)

PETITIONS
Presentation
Mr VASTA (Bonner) (10:01): On behalf of the Chair of the Petitions Committee, I present the following 47 petitions.
Aviation Industry
Certain Institutions within Australia have blocked the opportunity for more international flights due to national interests, without providing a counter solution to the required demand.
As Australians, we believe in free and open markets, however, when demand exceeds supply, additional supply is being blocked without economical reason.
We therefore ask the House to reverse their decision on denying additional flights from reputable airline(s).
Reserve Bank is tackling inflation, yet, the opportunity to reduce the opportunity of Australians to travel abroad at fair market price is being denied.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN5453)
Endometriosis

Endometriosis is a chronic and often debilitating medical condition that impacts the lives of countless women, including myself. I have personally experienced the challenges and pain associated with this condition for years, until I discovered a medication called Visanne. This medication has been a game-changer for me, enabling me to lead a pain-free life and significantly improving my quality of life. However, there is a pressing issue surrounding Visanne that I believe deserves attention.

Visanne, while highly effective, is unfortunately an expensive medication that many women with endometriosis cannot afford. The most affordable option I have found costs $70 a month, a significant financial burden for individuals like me who may also have other medical conditions, such as anxiety, and other financial responsibilities to manage. It is deeply concerning to think about the younger women who are juggling work, studies, and daily expenses while also facing the choice between purchasing groceries or the medication that allows them to live without excruciating pain.

The financial challenges posed by the cost of Visanne have been exacerbated by recent inflation and economic difficulties that have affected us all. In this context, I kindly request that you consider taking action to help women in our community who suffer from endometriosis access this vital medication by adding it to the PBS.

We therefore ask the House to support women suffering from Endometriosis in adding Visanne to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) to improve access to better treatment for women managing chronic pain.
from 109 citizens (Petition No. EN5454)
Assistance for Isolated Children Scheme
Many children living in remote regions of Australia do not have adequate daily access to a physical secondary school and therefore must board away from home to attend school.

Accessing compulsory schooling through boarding institutions comes at a considerable cost to geographically isolated families. Recent survey data, collected from a cross-section of ICPA members nationwide, showed that more than 75% of respondents bear out-of-pocket expenses of over $5000.00 per term just for boarding fees and essential travel. This gap is their out-of-pocket expenses after they receive the Federal Government's Assistance for Isolated Children (AIC) Basic Boarding Allowance (BBA0. That is an out-of-pocket gap of over $20,000 per year per student. These calculations do not include the additional costs of school or tuition fees. This expense is becoming increasingly unsustainable.

With the disparity between the AIC Boarding Allowance and the actual cost of boarding fees across Australia continues to grow, impacting on the allowance's intent and effectiveness. Rural and remote families are required to contribute increasingly more towards the cost of their children's compulsory education year after year with only incremental annual increases to the allowance.

We therefore ask the House to urgently increase to the Federal Governments Assistance for Isolated Children Basic Boarding Allowance by at least $4000 to more adequately cover the increasing costs of educating rural and remote children.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN5455)
Aviation Industry

We request the Australian government establish an enforceable passenger compensation scheme to address the persistent issues faced by airline passengers who endure delays and cancellations. The primary motivation behind this initiative is to safeguard the rights and well-being of travellers while promoting accountability within the aviation industry, something that is lacking at the moment.

Australians heavily rely on air travel for connectivity, making timely and reliable flights essential. However, passengers often find themselves stranded at airports due to unforeseen delays or abrupt cancellations, causing substantial inconvenience and financial loss. A compensation scheme would provide much-needed recourse for affected travelers.

Moreover, such a scheme would incentivise airlines to improve their operational efficiency and communication with passengers. It would discourage airlines from overbooking flights or routinely rescheduling, rerouting and cancelling departures without adequate notice. Passengers invest not just money but also time and trust in airlines, which should be reciprocated with a commitment to service and punctuality. The current system isn't working, and the lack of competition means passengers have no choice and no recourse when things go wrong. The airlines know this.

We therefore ask the House to implement an enforceable passenger compensation scheme to protect the interests of airline passengers in Australia. It would not only alleviate the hardships faced by travelers but also encourage airlines to prioritise punctuality and customer satisfaction. By taking this step, the Australian government can enhance the overall travel experience and strengthen its commitment to consumer rights in the aviation sector.
from 27 citizens (Petition No. EN5456)
Skilled Migration Program

As of 10 Sep 2023, the Department of Home Affairs website published 189 visa processing time is 90% of visa applications finalised in 8 months for Points-Tested Stream. For 190 visa, it is 13 months. In reality, many waits longer than that for their visa grant, especially if the occupation is not related to allied health and various teaching occupations.

While visa applicants wait for the visa to be finalised, they are unable to realistically undertake many activities, such as taking a mortgage, finding a partner, finding a better job, planning to have kids or starting a business. Their lives are basically at pause because they cannot make material changes of their circumstances, otherwise their visa could get refused. On top of that, the amount of uncertanty caused by long waiting time can have impact on health, creating another risk factor that their visa might be refused because of degrading health, as the health examination for visa purpose is only valid for 12 months.

We therefore ask the House to urge the Department of Home Affairs to finalise on-hand 189 and 190 visa applications as quickly as possible. Visa applicants want certainty, not indefinite pause of their lives.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN5459)
Health Care

children under 18 years old who consume more than 2 energy drinks a day the chemicals that are within those drinks can cause dependence, dehydration, insomnia, and heart palpitations. thus causing health issues for them in later teen years and early adult life. thus we ask for a bill to create the legal age of being able to buy energy drinks. to 18 years old for protection for the younger Australians.

We therefore ask the House to raise the legal age of being able to buy energy drinks in Australia to 18 years old. if we keep allowing children under 18 years old to consume and buy high-level caffeine energy drinks what are we setting for the next-gen of kids to fall into the same habits??
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN5461)
Environment: Japan

On 24 August 2023, Tokyo Electric Power (TEPCO) was allowed by Japanese government to discharge nuclear-contaminated water into the Pacific Ocean with a decades-long plan to dump 1.34 Million cubic meres of wastewater-around 540 Olympic Swimming pools's worth, which has been used to cool the plant's wrecked reactors. The Fukushima nuclear disaster was a major nuclear disaster caused by the 2011 Tohoku earthquake and tsunami on 11 March 2011, and causing a loss of power and leading to three nuclear meldowns, 3x hydrogen explosions, and the release of radioactive contamination. Since then, water has been used to keep the three damaged reactors from overheating with the contaminated water being stored in about 1000 tanks. The Japanese nuclear-contaminated water dumped now has fundamental difference from the discharge of the nuclear plants which are normally operated in terms of the category of radionuclides, original source or disposal treatment imparity. Dumping any sort of waste water including nuclear contaminated waste water would pose serious risk to our delicate ecosystem and ultimately the world including Australia. Japanese nuclear contaminated wastewater will carry the contaminants like tritium and radionuclides, it eventually will damage Australians marine life and our human health. Please Stand up and protect our Australia!

We therefore ask the House to review the Statement by DFAT on the release of ALPS treated waste water from the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant, its ALPS is not transparent, and We need the Japanese government to stop dumping their nuclear contaminated wastewater into the Pacific Ocean
from 20 citizens (Petition No. EN5462)
Environment: Japan

Despite being treated, according to Melbourne University's Opening the Flood Gates to Fukushima by Nobel Prize winner, 70% of the water has levels of radionuclides above regulatory standards, with some cases 20000 times higher including tritium and other more harmful chemicals. The contaminated water released into the ocean is irreversible and can be linked to all kinds of negative effects on the environment, ecosystems, living organisms, humans.
It is preventable- there are other options available to store the radioactive water however they have been rejected due to expense.
It is against international law to dump radioactive water into the ocean. If we allow it, all countries will disregard international laws.

Prior to the article, there was a lack of information that was received, however we cannot continue to allow the dumping of radioactive water into the ocean if we want our future generations to be able to live a safe and fulfilling life in a country surrounded by the blue ocean where they can swim in and enjoying seafood without any worries. Any action taken sooner is better, however, we can still limit the effects this may have to our environment by trying to stop Japan's release, especially since there are safer options available and it is so dangerous.

We therefore ask the House to review the dangers of the radioactive water release into the Pacific and to urgently stop supporting the release. We request an external, holistic and detailed report of all chemicals present in the water.
from 33 citizens (Petition No. EN5463)
Mental Health
1. Over 3,000 deaths by suicide occur each year in Australia (ABS)
2. Suicide is the leading cause of death for young people (ABS)
3. Australian farmers (45%) have had thoughts of self-harm or suicide, while close to a third (30%) have attempted self-harm or suicide.—National Farmer Wellbeing Report 2023
4. The cost of living crisis has put enormous strain upon Australians and therefore rapid decline of mental health
5. Non subsidised Medicare mental health sessions costs are expensive (starting at $120+ per appointment)
We therefore ask the House to consider to restore the number of Medicare subsided mental health sessions to 20 as they are many Australians struggling with their mental health
from 269 citizens (Petition No. EN5465)
Skilled Migration Program

I am writing to express my deep concern and frustration regarding the significant backlog in processing 190 visas from the year 2021 and earlier. Our families have been eagerly waiting for our visa application to be processed, and the prolonged delay has caused us significant stress and uncertainty. The extensive backlog has created a tremendous burden on the lives of many individuals and families who are eagerly awaiting the opportunity to contribute to Australian society. The huge backlog needs to be processed urgently.

We therefore ask the House to process our cases with compassion and urgency. We have diligently followed the application process and met all the requirements, and it is only fair that we are provided with timely updates and decisions on our visa applications. Receiving over two S56 and not having a visa processed un less than 28 days it's unfair and frustrating for all applicants.
Thank you for your attention to this matter. We look forward to a swift resolution and the opportunity to contribute to the beautiful nation of Australia.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN5466)
Iran
1. Public Interest & National Security: The country's safety and international reputation necessitate implementing the Senate Foreign Affairs and Trade committee's recommendations.

2. Accountability: Australians elected the government expecting transparency, accountability, and prioritisation of national interests. Ignoring key recommendations related to security breaches this trust.
3. Human Rights Values: Australia's identity as a defender of human rights and democratic values makes it unsettling when crucial recommendations are ignored.
4. National Reputation: Australia's prominent role in global affairs risks being tarnished by neglecting these recommendations.
5. Perceived Hypocrisy: Publicly supporting the Iranian populace while engaging with the Islamic Republic, notorious for human rights abuses, damages Australia's credibility
We therefore ask the House to
1. Urge the Australian Government and Attorney General to reconsider their position in line with public sentiment laid out in the petition reasons.
2. Demand a government statement addressing Australian concerns and indicating a reevaluation.

3. Introduce necessary Bills under "Emergency Situations" and using "Suspension of Standing Orders" mechanisms to enable expeditious enactment of recommendations of the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee inquiry.
4. Establish a dedicated parliamentary debate on the findings of the Senate Committee inquiry
5. Demand regular public report on the government's progress in evaluating and implementing the recommendations
from 527 citizens (Petition No. EN5467)
Veterans
The intent of those that drafted the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986, was for adverse decisions of Repatriation Commission to be automatically reviewed...

The Ministers Advisory Committee, which was comprised of the heads of Ex-Service Organisations, recommend an amendment be made, so the veteran would be, "required to indicate that they wished to proceed (with the review)". This recommendation was adopted, and a 12 month appeal window was also introduced...

Statute time frames for seeking review exist under ADJR, AAT and other Acts, however in order natural justice prevails, these Acts also include an extension provision, which are routinely approved, some many years after the decision was made...

That no extension exists in relation to a review of a decision of the Repatriation Commission is an evident failing of natural justice, to address this failing the undersigned request an ADJR/AAT type extension be appropriately introduced into the VEA...

This request becomes more reasonable given the adversarial approach and excessive time taken by the Repatriation Commission in deciding claims, the submissive relationship ESOs have adopted in dealing with DVA, the systemic reliance on amateur advocates, and especially the known multitude of mental and physical health diseases and injuries which veterans suffer as a result of their defence service.

We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes, as to cause an amendment to the VEA that allows for a veteran to access an extension provision of decisions of the Repatriation Commission, such as that which exists under the AAT, ADJR etc.
from 51 citizens (Petition No. EN5468)
Geoengineering

Inquiry into geoengineering, what is being sprayed into the air? Who is doing this? What is their motivation? Are all nations privy to what is going on? Is climate change due to this manipulation of weather, fires, floods etc by some for financial gain? Are we being played to the financial and health detriment to Australian citizens? Are the climate emergencies eg fires, floods etc being used to hide the fact that their experiments have caused irreparable damage to the atmosphere? No country should be able to manipulate the weather and makes citizens of the world suffer whilst some gain from what they are deliberately doing.

We therefore ask the House to inquire as to the effect of geoengineering on the climate, air quality and atmosphere and if detrimental changes are due to geo engineering, then this should be evaluated for safety of future generations and not allow vested interest groups to destroy the environment under the lie of trying to protect it. Geoengineering should be stopped.
from 20 citizens (Petition No. EN5472)
Paid Parental Leave Scheme

Our government recommends breastfeeding for the first year of a child's life. This is challenging to do if one is required to go back to work after paid parental leave ends. Some women cannot pump breastmilk or have the ability to work from home to continue breastfeeding their baby. Employees are only entitled to 4 weeks of annual leave a year therefore, unless the employer has their own scheme in place, the most paid leave a woman can take is 6 months. It is not uncommon either for a woman to commence her maternity leave one month prior to her baby's due date. Changing the scheme to one year additionally alleviates pressure from daycares, caretakers such as grandparents and removes unwanted guilt from the mother for returning to work so soon.
An employer must keep an employee's job who goes on paid parental leave for a year regardless.
If it is recommended to breastfeed for one year, why should a mother rely on formula simply to go back to work?
Our children are our future and therefore, must come first
We therefore ask the House to amend the paid parental leave scheme from 20 weeks paid leave to one year.
from 34 citizens (Petition No. EN5473)
Pensions and Benefits

Please remove all relationship status considerations from Centrelink payments. Treating all people as individuals, not forcing the pooling of finances, allowing individual financial freedoms and particularly taking the pressure off disabled families who often have one person bearing the brunt of all medical expenses, while the disabled person is a financial burden.

Removing relationship status will decrease the work load of already overrun centrelink staff, allowing them to process applications faster and answer more phone calls—so it will save the government money in that regard. It will add precious money into the economy (we know people on low incomes spend money on essentials which boosts the economy), and give people more financial freedom, less stress, less privacy invasions (like the questions about your sexual relations).
Removing relationship status will give many people the freedom to leave abusive relationships more easily, to have control of their own finances.

It's about providing the most vulnerable in our society with some financial freedom and autonomy. It's about allowing disabled people to contribute to their own expenses, even if they have a partner earning a reasonable wage.

There are countless examples of situations where this change would bring about long lasting and positive effects for both individuals, society and the economy. A progressive social welfare system is the goal.

We therefore ask the House to remove relationship status as a consideration for all Centrelink payments. Make eligibility for a payment based on your individual circumstances, not on your partner's income.
from 29 citizens (Petition No. EN5477)
Corporate Governance: Online Services

In today's digital age, consumers engage with online platforms and services, often necessitating recurring payments, or trial periods. While this can be convenient, it's become increasingly predatory when companies continue to rebill accounts that have remained inactive for extended periods.

Many users might become incapacitated, pass away, or simply forget about these dormant accounts. Yet, without any service provision or engagement, these companies persistently draw funds. This is not just an oversight; it's an exploitative practice. A user's inactivity, especially over prolonged periods, should signal the potential need for a review or cessation of charges. Instead, many face financial drains for services they no longer use or might be unaware they're even paying for.

By ending automatic rebilling for inactive accounts, we protect consumers from undue financial burdens and ensure that companies act in good faith, aligning their revenue with actual service provision. This change will promote fairness and integrity in online business practices, urging companies to prioritize genuine service over opportunistic profit.

We therefore ask the House to Introduce and pass legislation that mandates online service providers to review and cease automatic rebilling for accounts that have remained inactive for a specified duration. This legislation should require these companies to notify users of their inactivity and give them an option to continue or discontinue the service before any further charges are applied. By implementing this change, the House will be protecting consumers at the federal level from unwarranted financial drains.
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN5478)
First Nations Australians
As The Voice to Parliament debate hots up, a more pressing issue is why Indigenous Australians are NOT benefitting from the huge Annual budget of some $40Billion.

We therefore ask the House to hold a Royal Commission into the Indigenous Budget to determine accountability and costs incurred in the distribution of all these funds. This will hopefully expose all/any scams and thefts of these funds.
from 17 citizens (Petition No. EN5481)
Aviation Industry
Dear Sir/Madam,
I write to you on behalf of the Australian immigrant community, appealing for critical improvements in travel accessibility, specifically focusing on affordable flights and service quality.

Australia's legacy of embracing immigrants from diverse backgrounds enriches our nation both culturally and economically. Travel is an essential lifeline for immigrants, connecting them with their roots, families, and global networks.
1. **Financial Hurdles**: The exorbitant airfare costs, especially during peak times, impose significant financial burdens on immigrants, forcing many to endure prolonged separations from loved ones.

2. **Service Standards**: All travelers, including immigrants, deserve a secure and comfortable travel experience. Yet, the service quality on some economical flights often falls below acceptable standards, causing discomfort and dissatisfaction.

3. **Accessibility Gaps**: Insufficient flight options and routes, particularly in underserved regions, hinder immigrants from accessing affordable and convenient travel choices, impacting their connections with their home countries.
We therefore ask the House to consider the following actions:
1. **Subsidized Air Travel**: Investigate the feasibility of subsidizing airfare for immigrants during pivotal family events or emergencies to ease the financial burden.
2. **Service Enhancement**: Collaborate with airlines to raise the service quality on economical flights, ensuring that all passengers, including immigrants, enjoy safe and comfortable journeys.
3. **Expanded Accessibility**: Vigorously work towards expanding flight route options, especially in remote areas, providing immigrants with more travel choices and convenience.
Addressing these concerns will not only alleviate immigrants' hardships but also reinforce their commitment to Australia, fostering unity and integration.
Sincerely,
Australian Community
from 32 citizens (Petition No. EN5483)
COVID-19: Response

the federal government has announced that they will conduct an enquiry into the state and federal governments response to the COVID19 pandemic. The terms of this enquiry are limited and fail to look at the roll of various states and how they handled border closures and lockdowns. State premiers may have overstepped their powers given to them and as such citizens don't want to see a repeat in the event of another pandemic.
We therefore ask the House to call for a public enquiry into the response to COVID-19 by the states.
from 39 citizens (Petition No. EN5484)
Personal Information and Privacy

The requirement to show ID has been brought in under the guise of making things harder for criminals—to prevent title theft, clamp down on illegal immigration, prevent money laundering, prevent funding of terrorism, etc. However, the requirement to show ID is a denial of the presumption of innocence. One of the main concerns of a centralised digital ID system is that it would be used to cut political opponents off from participating in the economy. We saw a taste of this during the so-called pandemic, when state governments imposed vaccine mandates, requiring people to show vaccine certificates connected to their identity. People were denied employment and services based on private medical information connected to their identity. This is a concrete example of how ID requirements have been abused. And given that no level of government has acknowledged that vaccine mandates were wrong, there is no reason to believe that something like this won't happen again. This centralised digital ID is being touted as voluntary, but if something will eventually be compulsory, then it was never really voluntary. And there is good reason to believe that a government-issued digital ID will soon be compulsory, with many countries floating the idea of digital currencies and requiring an ID to access the internet. There are security concerns, as well, with everyone's ID and other personal details being stored in a centralised system.
We therefore ask the House to reject the 2023 Digital ID Bill.
from 106 citizens (Petition No. EN5485)
Housing
We have a housing affordability and availability crisis in Australia.

We therefore ask the House to introduce a 100% capital gains tax on Australian real estate transfers including primary places of residence, with the government required to spend all revenue on building houses.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5486)
Domestic and Family Violence

The Northern Territory has by far the highest rates of domestic, family and sexual violence (DFSV) in Australia—three times the national average. The rate of domestic homicide is seven times the national average.

The NT Coroner is currently investigating the deaths of four Aboriginal women from domestic violence. The evidence presented to the Coroner has been damning. The system is buckling under the weight of the need. And since the inquests have started two more women have been killed.
Neither the NT Government nor the Commonwealth Government are doing enough to stop the violence.

Part of the problem is that the Commonwealth Government provides funding to states and territories based on population, rather than need. The NT has a small population so its share of national funding is never sufficient given the extreme level of need in the Territory.
'Needs-based funding' rather than 'population-based funding' could make a huge difference to NT women's lives.
We therefore ask the House to commit to needs-based funding so that the NT's share of Commonwealth funding reflects the demonstrably higher rates of DFSV in the NT.
We further call upon the House to achieve:
1. An immediate injection of funds to tackle DFSV, of at least $180 million over five years.

2. The immediate establishment and ongoing funding of a DFSV Peak Organisation for the Northern Territory to enable the non-government sector to proactively contribute to systemic improvements in DFSV responses.
3. The allocation of 50% of the 1200 allocated houses in the NT to victim-survivors of DFSV.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN5490)
Assange, Mr Julian Paul

We the People of Australia demand that our House of Representatives act with strength concerning the matter of Julian Assange. The UK and the US engage in grave abuse of human rights. Julian Assange, an Australian citizen and journalist, has been subject to internationally recognised torture. He faces unjust extra-territorial prosecution by the US and UK for publishing information of public interest. If the Australian Government weakly allows our allies to engage in such abuse of an Australian citizen, this places all Australians at risk. The precedent poses a significant threat to individual Australians and our national security. Any Australian citizen travelling abroad now faces such extra-territorial prosecution and indeed, torture. This threat must be acknowledged by the Australian Government and dealt with. Statements by Anthony Blinken that Australia "understand our concerns about this matter" indicate that the US seeks to normalise human rights abuse and torture of Australian citizens. We do not tolerate this, and ask our representatives to act forthrightly in accordance with the rights of Julian and the Australian People. As Senator Penny Wong stated regarding sanctions on other nations committing human rights abuse: "The government will bring all aspects of Australian power to our foreign policy, employ every strategy at our disposal towards upholding rights consistent with our values and our interests." We demand the same resolve in the case of Julian Assange.
We therefore ask the House to apply targeted sanctions on the UK, the US, and specific officials responsible for the abuse against Assange.
from 48 citizens (Petition No. EN5493)
Agriculture Industry
Farms are in trouble and need help
We therefore ask the House to investigate farms and bad treatment they are getting

Shops need to be investigated on buying practices. They shouldn't be allowed to offer. example $3 a kilo then sell for $35 a kilo to public .shops manipulated the market force farmers to buy at their price
from 17 citizens (Petition No. EN5495)
Live Animal Exports
Live exports should be allowed after a investigation

We therefore ask the House to investigate the live export businesses. Australia makes millions from export. Maybe boats could be subsidized.to take less livestock as not to pack in the animals give them space to walk and appoint a vet to go with livestock.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN5496)
Skilled Migration Program

Prior to Covid, a number of individuals were encouraged to move to Regional Areas. During Covid a number of overseas candidates left the country due inadequate assistance. After Covid, the remaining Skilled applicants left in the regional areas are facing a tremendous delays for an outcome including myself.
We therefore ask the House to please accept our plea to expedite permanent resident visas so that the skilled workers are not facing exploitation due to the shortcomings of the immigration system.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN5497)
International Relations: Australia and India

We are deeply concerned and dismayed regarding recent events related to India's interference in foreign countries and allegations of the assassination of citizens of friendly nations who hold dissenting views towards the Indian regime.

As concerned citizens of Australia, we believe that our country's foreign policy and security alliances should be guided by principles of peace, democracy, and respect for human rights. Recent reports and incidents have raised serious questions about the alignment of our nation's interests with those of India, and we urge our government to reevaluate its security partnership with India.

Specifically, we are deeply troubled by recent assassinations of Canadian citizens and sikh activists in Canada by Indian officials. Also, we would like to divert your attention towards the hate speech and derogatory activities against the Sikh Australian community by the hindu indian nationalists in Australia early this year. These actions not only endanger the lives of innocent individuals but also undermine the values and principles that our country upholds on the international stage.
We therefore ask the House to take the following actions:
Reevaluate the existing security alliance with India in light of recent events and consider whether it aligns with our country's values and interests.
Conduct a thorough and impartial investigation into the allegations of India's involvement in unlawful activities in foreign countries.
Propose exclusion of India from the Quad alliance, with the aim of reassessing our strategic alignment, security, and diplomatic engagements.
Ensure transparency and accountability in our foreign policy decisions and alliances to maintain the trust of our citizens.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN5499)
Iran

Respected Members of Parliament, we seek your support for the Iranian-Australian community in facilitating a vital meeting with Crown Prince Reza Pahlavi to advance democratic change in Iran. Such a meeting holds immense relevance for Australia, aligning with democratic values and fostering economic opportunities potentially worth trillions of dollars. It elevates Australia's global standing and promotes regional stability.

Crown Prince Reza Pahlavi, an advocate for democracy and human rights, enjoys overwhelming popularity among Iranians. His vision for Iran emphasizes secular democracy, political freedom, inclusivity, and free elections. He has actively engaged with the international community, including an official visit to Israel, conveying a message of peace through the Cyrus Accords.

In contrast to some other opposition groups who are often missing a clear vision for a post-regime Iran, with instances of alignment with the Islamic Republic's positions on subjects such as Israel, regional peace, and inclusion, his leadership stands out as a credible and compelling force for positive change.

This diplomatic engagement offers a unique opportunity to strengthen relations and access Iran's burgeoning market, specifically in mining and farming industries. His commitment to democracy ensures that any future Iranian government would be chosen through fair and free elections, aligning with Australia's values.
We therefore ask the House to facilitate such meeting and engage in this diplomatic endeavour, which holds great potential for mutual benefit, regional peace, and economic growth.
from 481 citizens (Petition No. EN5506)
Australian National Anthem
I bring forth this petition to address a matter of cultural significance—the recent alteration of the Australian national anthem, specifically the change of the phrase "For we are young and free."

This petition seeks to advocate for the reinstatement of the original wording in recognition of the soldiers who, through their unwavering commitment and sacrifice, defended the principles symbolized by our national anthem. The removal of this poignant line is viewed by many as a disservice to the memory of those who laid down their lives in defense of our freedom.

By affixing your signature to this petition, you contribute to a collective call for the restoration of the anthem to its initial form. Let us stand united in preserving the historical and cultural significance embedded in these words, honoring the sacrifices made by those who have served our nation.
Sign the petition today to convey your support for upholding the integrity and legacy of the Australian national anthem.
We therefore ask the House to restore the original wording "For we are young and free" in the Australian national anthem.
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN5507)
International Health Regulations

We are concerned that Parliament has not discussed and have had no say on the 307 proposed amendments to the IHR that were adopted by the 75th World Health Assembly 27th May 2022.Australia has the authority to reject them under Article 61 of the IHR but any rejection must be made by within 18 months of adoption (Dec 2023) Parliament must be given the opportunity to vote on whether to reject the amendments that have already been adopted, the 307 proposed amendments that are currently being negotiated by delegates to the World Health Assembly. Has Australia proposed any of these amendments? The UK hasn't so who is making these amendments and are they being made for the good of citizens or some other agenda? Whose interests will this power and control benefit?

We therefore ask the House to read and discuss these amendments. Work out if the amendments are for health reasons or our nation will lose Sovereignty and our citizens will lose freedom of health decisions. Parliament works for the Australian public and as such Globalist agendas should be secondary to what is best for the Nation. No agreement should be made until Parliament has read and discussed the implications of this agreement which on reading risks our country not being able to make its own health outcomes. The Prime Minister is able to write a letter to the WHO and invoke Article 61 and reject the IHR for our nation. This in my opinion is the safest outcome.
from 49 citizens (Petition No. EN5509)
International Health Regulations

We request that Parliament vote on whether to accept or reject the amendments to the International Health Regulations (2005) that were adopted by the 75th World Health Assembly on 27 May 2022. Every nation, including Australia, has the authority to reject these amendments under Article 61 of the IHR, but any such rejection must be within 18 months of their adoption. This must be done before the end of November 2023. The changes to Article 59 of the IHR would shorten the time for future amendments to enter into force from 24 to 12 months and would shorten the period of time for rejection or reservations to be submitted from 18 to 10 months. We object to these changes. The amendments to the IHR that were adopted on 27 May 2022 have not been debated in or voted on by Parliament. This is compounded by the fact that an additional 307 proposed amendments are currently being negotiated by the Working Group on Amendments to the International Health Regulations (WGIHR). The people of Australia have not had an opportunity to express their opinions regarding these legally-binding changes to international law.

We therefore ask the House to respect the will of the people of Australia and vote to reject the amendments to the International Health Regulations that were adopted by the World Health Assembly on 27 May 2022.
from 472 citizens (Petition No. EN5517)
Glioblastoma

Currently the only standard of care for Glioblastoma patients include surgery, radiation and chemotherapy. Even with this treatment the average survival is 12 months. Tumour treating fields such as the Optune device have been proven to increase overall survival rate. This treatment is FDA approved but is not TGA approved and therefore cannot be prescribed in Australia. Please support us to make a change to make this device TGA approved and therefore available to Australians suffering from Glioblastoma.
We therefore ask the House to approve the use of Tumour Treating Fields such as the Optune device for use in Australia. (TGA approved)
from five citizens (Petition No. EN5518)
Medicare

The Medicare Benefits rebate freeze was first introduced by Labor in the 2013-14 Budget as a temporary measure to July 2014. The Coalition reimposed the freeze in MYEFO 2014-15 and then extended in subsequent budgets to July 2020.
The alterations to the rebate have not been enough for GPs to continue to provide services without charging cash up front.
Since 2013 inflation has been about 25% and the increase for the Medicare Benefits rebate has been close to zero.
The taxes we the people pay have increased yearly meaning the 2% Medicare levy money paid has increased yearly but the payments to doctors hasn't.
The petitioner lives in a town where bulk billing even for pensioners has been discontinued.
We therefore ask the House to increase the Medicare Benefits rebate by an amount that would allow GPs to bulk bill everyone and to legislate that GPs must bulk bill for all.
from 239 citizens (Petition No. EN5528)
COVID-19: Mortality

In Queensland covid deaths are no longer published by the state government, they are given to the Federal Department of Health. Federal Health do not show actual numbers on their web site, just a dinky graph where true numbers can not be ascertained. Federal Health web site gives a link to a pdf file which at the time of submitting this petition had data nearly 3 months old and for a 5 month time period, nothing recent.
The true covid deaths data is being hidden from we the people.

We therefore ask the House to instruct the Federal Department of Health to release weekly covid death numbers so that we the people can continue to monitor the 21st century covid plague and know how many of us are being killed by it. Hiding the data is not part of the democratic process.
from 21 citizens (Petition No. EN5529)
Asylum Seekers
1. Refugees are putting strain in our Health Care System they had more benefits than ordinary Australian, they had a free Dental Care whilst as ordinary citizens are not eligible
2. NDIS funding is shrinking due to Refugees had disabilities and need to be funded
3. Rental Availability in Australia is almost zero, the government is prioritizing Refugees to had the house with low-cost rent

We therefore ask the House to stop accepting Refugees from IRAQ/SYRIA to Australia, almost every family of Refugees had one which had disability and they put too much money taken out from NDIS FUNDING, most of the refugees had mental disabilities and in which they are a potential threat to community crimes in the future if NDIS is not able to give them the right FUNDING. Also, they are one of the reasons why out we do not have rental availability in the housing sector, 15000 refugees came to Australia every year which making Rental Availability in Australia to almost nothing.
from 26 citizens (Petition No. EN5536)
Aviation Industry

Additional flights by Qatar Airways are very likely to benefit Australian economy and international travellers to and from Australia. Every tourist coming in to Australia would have more choices for airfares and flights schedules which may tip on their decision to visit Australia. Every tourist coming in to Australia would benefit Australia by their tourist spending whilst in Australia. Australian travellers would gain more choices for selecting suitable airfares to wide network of Qatar Airways, and that may mean shorter overall travel times to and from Africa, Europe and western Asia. Newly approved Qatar Airways flights would bring welcome competition and lower airfares to Australians, as well as direct benefit to Virgin Australia who are partners with Qatar Airways. Qatar flights would feed in to Virgin Australia network on codeshare agreements.
We therefore ask the House to approve additional Qatar Airways flights in and out of Australia.
from 35 citizens (Petition No. EN5537)
Nuclear Energy

The Minister for Trade and Tourism Special Minister of State, the Defence Industry Minister for International Development and the Pacific, the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence, the Minister of Defence Science, the Minister for Industry and Science and the Minister for Climate Change and Energy and the Minister for the Environment and Water? Reports miss the real world. The US and the UK already enacted laws during this time to separate Fission and Fusion and to free Fusion from the constraints of nuclear legislation that obstruct its development and acceptance. There's a fusion dialogue on sovereignty and security with them. FIA announced a future energy source available in the 2030s. Known to be the option safer than nuclear fission, with no radiological waste. Australia's government-funded offshore development by the HB11 group in this industry? OUR future is without Fission energy for electricity, ships, space, defence, or planes.

We therefore ask the House to enact laws to separate Fission and Fusion and to free Fusion from the constraints of nuclear legislation that obstruct its development and acceptance. Why hasn't the government provided funds to sciences, education, and industry to create businesses and employment, to progress and acknowledge its safety and significance to trade with the S.E. Asian region?
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN5544)
Skilled Migration Program

There has been long delays in the processing of 190 visa which is causing acute depression and stress in the people who have invested life, money , study and their resources in Australia. Some people are waiting more than 2 years for the grant and their life is on hold as they can't marry, can't get a house or car loan as they need a permanent visa for that. Adversely affected are those people who are on Bridging C visa for all these years and can't even go home to visit their family in the times of happiness and sorrow as the visa has travel restrictions. This backlog for people who have applied 190 is giving alot of stress and putting the applicants lives on hold.

We therefore ask the House to finalise all the 190 visa applications for people who are waiting for more than 12 months , so that they can carry on with their lives. And also like to advocate for abolishing travel restrictions on bridging visa C so that people can travel and see their families in time of need and emergency and can come back to Australia.
from 60 citizens (Petition No. EN5545)
Migration

Visa 309 applicants whose visas are pending in Amman Office. The Amman Office takes too long to process a partner visa. The offices in other places like indonesia, Japan , Fiji process a visa in minimum 2 months. However, the Amman Office takes 1 to 2 years for processing. There are case that have
even surpassed the period of 2 years. Why are australian citizens and PR holders kept away from their partners who are living outside australia and are waiting for their offshore partner visa.
The department doesn't issue any visitors visa easily either so that their partners can come and visit them.

Onshore 820 visas are processed quite quickly, but not offshore 309 despite charging the same amount. If Amman Office has a backlog of cases from different countries then atleast process the visas from each country in their respective country. My husband is from pakistan, and I want that the pakistani partner visas be processed in pakistan.

We therefore ask the House to take an action about this and speed up the Visa 309 Process especially in Amman Office, or atleast move the visa processing for each country to their respective countries instead of bulking up thousands of Visa applications from several countries in Amman.
from 259 citizens (Petition No. EN5547)

subdebateinfo.title: National Disability Insurance Scheme: First Nations Australians

p.span: National Disability Insurance Scheme: First Nations Australians

NDIS has been supporting individuals and their families for 10 years, in this time the structures and processes have been lead by western view, western way and western connections. Aboriginal families have been struggling to receive effective cultural support from NDIS for 10 years and in some cases identity has completely been dismissed as irrelevant to having a disability. Aboriginal peoples have no direct funding to directly engage cultural supports, cultural healing practices and cultural connections. Mainstream services access an Aboriginal participants NDIS budget to include social participation and often does not include any cultural value to the participants daily lives. Cultural healing practices do not fit the criteria of Allied Health according to the NDIS guidelines and Aboriginal participants are not able to access healing through their NDIS plans that is culturally responsive and supportive. By excluding cultural supports in NDIS budgeting means Aboriginal participants and their families are struggling to feel connected and supported from services. Mainstream services are utilising budgets and excluding cultural needs in the process.

We therefore ask the House to consider adding a budget component to Aboriginal participants NDIS plans that are culturally exclusive for practices and supports that increase a participants cultural connection and healing practices. We also recommend that this budget only be accessible by Aboriginal companies and organisations for the purposes of cultural engagement and support. Big NGO's not be able to access this section of the budget even if they present a reasonable cultural plan.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN5549)
National Disability Insurance Scheme

Medical practitioners do not take time or care to support their patients in applying for NDIS, medical practitioners are not accountable for their role in NDIS applications and setting patients back months and sometimes years in being successful for NDIS applications when they need support and caring to be implemented. One doctor in a clinic in Blacktown had a tantrum in front of a patient and went to the management and refused to fill in forms, other examples are medical practitioners are writing the bare minimum and barely reading the questions. Patients should not be punished for the lack of doctor knowledge, care or willingness to take part in NDIS processes. The NDIS recommends participants call Local Area Coordinators who then say go to your doctor. The patient is not the medical professional yet they are writing their own NDIS applications for doctors to sign. One NDIS employee told a patient to doctor shop to get their paperwork filled out. Patients are being rejected 3-7 times and having to spend months, due to lack of medical support available when NDIS paperwork is needed. It is hard enough living with a disability, medical teams are causing mental and emotional harm.

We therefore ask the House to implement practice standards for NDIS and medical teams to ensure there are consequences for medical teams who are unwilling to support their patients, increase education for medical practitioners to understand their role in NDIS applications
from 17 citizens (Petition No. EN5550)
Australian Constitution

According to polls, the No campaign looks set to win by a large margin, but the Government is making it clear that it won't take no for an answer. The government is poised to blame the failure of the Voice on Chinese bots and neo-Nazis. In recent years, Western governments have demonstrated that they don't respect election and referendum results. Take Brexit as an example. For the last seven years the British establishment has sought to scupper Brexit. And if Labor wins next year's general election, Britain looks set to rejoin the EU. You could also look at the 2016 US presidential election. For four years, the establishment tried to undermine Trump's administration. They engineered his defeat in 2020. And they are now running a campaign to ensure that he won't be re-elected in 2024. The Voice referendum is shaping up to be Australia's Brexit moment, Australia's Trump moment. I am concerned that concerned that the referendum result will be used as a pretext to increase censorship, restrict freedom of speech and clamp down on dissent. All the rhetoric points to this.

We therefore ask the House to honour the result of the referendum. This means, if the Voice is rejected, not establishing a Voice to Parliament through legislation. It also means, whatever the outcome, not introducing any legislation in the name of clamping down on so-called "misinformation", "disinformation" or "foreign influence" during elections.
from 47 citizens (Petition No. EN5551)
First Nations Australians
To demonstrate that No voters are not "racists" and that they genuinely want to see a better life for remote communities.

We therefore ask the House to draw up a programme with top class professional administrators to urgently implement the provision of facilities for remote Aboriginal communities in order to improve their lives.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN5555)
Taxation

High inflation has resulted in a real wage decrease for millions of Australians. Raising the tax on the Rich and using the extra revenue to lower the tax on low to middle income Australians is simply a redistribution of wealth—There is zero extra money in circulation meaning zero impact on inflation.

We therefore ask the House to support the idea of raising the tax rate on big corporations and high income individuals and using the extra revenue collected to lower the tax rate for low to middle income Australians—Giving them a desperately needed pay rise.
from 190 citizens (Petition No. EN5557)
National Security

In the recent events of the pro Palestine protest I am asking for more deportation laws to deport anyone creating and participating in pro Palestine/ pro terrorist movements/ protests. And more protection laws and precautions before letting people in from overseas. I am concerned for Australians safety. Our Australian children deserve safety and protection! These terrorist do not like Australians they need to be deported.

We therefore ask the House to keep Australia safe by bringing in more deportation laws and protection laws for Australia. In the recent events of the pro Palestinian rally I am very concerned for all Australians and our safety. All of the people who attended need to be deported! And anyone who threatens Australians! stop letting them in! It is known that terrorists children are brainwashed at a young age. It is not safe for our Australian children. Bring in more safety laws for Australia. Deport these evil people they don't like Australians. They are threatening our lives. Please deport all pro Palestine/ pro terrorist protesters. The safety or Australians depend on it
from 24 citizens (Petition No. EN5560)
Parliament

The Australian community is multicultural and diverse, with people from various religious backgrounds and, increasingly, people identifying as not religious. On current trends, the proportion of Australians identifying as not religious will overtake Christians at the 2026 Census.
This diversity is evident in the nation's House of Representatives, with MPs identifying as Christian, Jewish, Muslim, Hindu, atheist, non-religious—and more.

Yet, each day in parliament, the Speaker asks all in attendance to observe two Christian prayers—one being the Lord's Prayer. Starting proceedings with an act of worship in the Christian tradition sends a message to non-Christians that they are not welcome and their worldviews are not respected.

Parliament is a pillar of our democracy. It should reflect modern Australia and be welcoming for all. It should be a secular institution that does not privilege one religious worldview above all others.

This petition is submitted on behalf of the sponsors of the first Secularism Australia Conference, being held in Sydney in December 2023. Jointly, we're calling for the House to lead by example in making government institutions—including parliaments and local councils—secular and welcoming for all.

We therefore ask the House to modernise the Standing Orders and to replace daily Christian prayers with a more appropriate practice. Such a practice could be, for example, a moment of silence to allow people to reflect or pray in a way that is meaningful to them, or a pledge to work in the public interest and in a manner befitting their responsibilities.
from 3,085 citizens (Petition No. EN5562)
Australian National Flag

We therefore ask the House to bring in flag laws for people living in Australia. It should be illegal to have a flag up that isn't aboriginal or Australian. Especially on Australia Day. It is disrespectful to Australia/Australians. It shows that they do not want to be apart of our culture and that they don't respect Australia. There needs to be penalties for people who raise a flag that isn't Australian or aboriginal. Please enforce warnings with fines then jail time and if they still continue to disrespect Australia deport them

We therefore ask the House to bring in flag laws for people living in Australia. It should be illegal to have a flag up that isn't aboriginal or Australian. Especially on Australia Day. It is disrespectful to Australia/Australians. It shows that they do not want to be apart of our culture and that they don't respect Australia. There needs to be penalties for people who raise a flag that isn't Australian or aboriginal. Please enforce warnings with fines then jail time and if they still continue to disrespect Australia deport them
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN5563)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Mr VASTA (Bonner) (10:01): On behalf of the Chair of the Petitions Committee, I present the following 65 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented.
Telecommunications
Dear Ms Templeman

I am writing in relation to correspondence of 14 February 2022 sent by the former Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, Mr Ken O'Dowd, to the former Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, the Hon Paul Fletcher MP, concerning Petition EN3653—Introduce Legislation to Ban Telecommunications Companies from Locking Phones to Their Networks, initiated by Ms Rebecca Smith.

I apologise for the time it has taken for a response to be provided to the Committee in relation to this matter. The petition was provided to the former Government, and was subsequently delayed due to oversights in the Department's handling procedures. The Department has put in place processes to make sure such a delay does not happen in the future.

The petition asked that the House of Representatives introduce legislation to ban telecommunications companies from locking phones to their network. The Australian Government does not have plans to prohibit telecommunications providers from locking phones to their network at this time.

Telecommunications providers tend to only issue locked mobile handsets for pre-paid services, particularly if the provider has subsidised the price of the handset. Sometimes these devices can be unlocked for a fee, depending on how long the device has been active.

There are other options in the market for customers seeking an unlocked phone. Post-paid handsets are not ordinarily locked to a particular network. Telecommunications providers also offer a number of SIM-only mobile phone plans, which allow consumers to use their existing handset, or purchase an unlocked handset from a variety of in-store or online retailers.

In addition, all companies that sell telecommunications products are required to provide a Critical Information Summary, which outlines what is included in the product being offered, the fees and charges, how long the contract lasts, and what a customer should do if they have a complaint. The information in the summary is designed to assist consumers to make informed choices about the products they are considering.

Information about what consumers should consider when selecting a new mobile device, or when entering into a contract with a service provider, is available on the website of the industry regulator, the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA), at www.acma.gov.au/understand-your-telco-contract.

If a consumer considers that they have been misinformed during the purchase of their mobile device, or if they experience difficulty unlocking their mobile handset directly with their provider, they can contact the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman (TIO) for assistance. The TIO is a free and independent alternative dispute resolution body for consumers with complaints about their telephone or internet service.

The TIO aims to settle disputes in a fair, objective and non-bureaucratic way, having regard not only to the law and to good industry practice, but also to what it considers is fair and reasonable. The TIO can be contacted via its website at www.tio.com.au/contact-us or by telephone on 1800 062 058.
I thank the Standing Committee for bringing Ms Smith's petition to the Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Nuclear Energy
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 to the Minister for Industry and Science, the Hon Ed Husic MP, regarding petition EN4147 to amend legislation prohibiting the use of nuclear fusion energy. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister responsible for Climate Change and Energy.

The Australian Government has committed to reducing emissions to 43 percent below 2005 levels by 2030 and to net zero by 2050. Nuclear fusion remains an experimental technology and will be developed and commercialised too slowly to help Australia meet these targets.

The International Atomic Energy Agency, for example, reports that the construction and operation of demonstration electricity-producing fusion power plants could occur by 2050, depending on funding and technical advancement.

The GenCost 2022-23 Report, prepared by the CSIRO and the Australian Energy Market Operator, shows that renewables are the cheapest form of generation for Australia, even when additional costs for storage and new transmission are included. Renewable technologies are quicker to build and cheaper to operate than nuclear power facilities.

The legislative prohibition on the approval of nuclear power plants under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 does not differentiate between nuclear technologies. The Australian Government has no plans to change the longstanding moratorium on nuclear power in Australia, or the laws which prohibit its deployment.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of this petition to the Government's attention.
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Housing
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4158 on creating an Access First Home Owners Grant—a grant of $50,000 directed towards people with disabilities, or their immediate carers.

The Albanese Government understands safe and affordable housing is central to the security and dignity of all Australians. Australia's Disability Strategy 2021—2031 (the Strategy) acknowledges the importance of appropriate housing as critical to a person's sense of home and their ability to participate in their communities. Policy Priority 1 under the Strategy commits all parties to increase the availability of affordable housing. This requires collaboration from all levels of government.

Through the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS), the Albanese Government funds Specialist Disability Accommodation (SDA) for eligible NDIS participants who cannot live in mainstream housing because of their particular support needs, or whose needs are most appropriately met by an SDA response.
The NDIS also has a range of home and living supports including home modifications that can support people with disability to reach their goals and live an independent life.

I note that on 29 September the final report of the Royal Commission into Violence, Abuse, Neglect and Exploitation of People with Disability was published. The report included a number of recommendations regarding housing for people with a disability. The Albanese Government announced a Commonwealth Disability Royal Commission Taskforce to coordinate the Government's response to the Royal Commission's recommendations.
More broadly, the Albanese Government is working with the state, territory and local governments to deliver better housing outcomes.
This includes the work being delivered through the National Cabinet to provide more secure and affordable housing supply. Significant measures include:

The National Housing Accord that will support planning and zoning reforms, as well as investing $350 million in additional federal funding to deliver 10,000 affordable rental homes over five years from 2024—matched by the state and territories.
Federal funding of $2 billion through the Social Housing Accelerator to deliver thousands of social homes across Australia.

Federal funding of $3 billion through the New Homes Bonus to help incentivise states and territories to build more homes where people need them to meet a new national target of 1.2 million new homes over five years.

A $500 million Housing Support Program for initiatives to help kick start housing supply including connecting essential services, amenities to support new housing development or building planning capability.
A National Planning Reform Blueprint with planning, zoning, land release and other measures to improve housing supply and affordability.
A Better Deal for Renters to harmonise and strengthen renters' rights across Australia.
In addition to these are the measures that are being delivered to support Australians purchase their own home.

The Albanese Government is also working with states and territories to deliver the Help to Buy Scheme, supporting up to 40,000 low and middle income families to purchase a home of their own through a shared equity approach. This will bring home ownership back into reach for thousands of Australians who have been locked out of the housing market.
Help to Buy will commence in 2024, and be open to a maximum of 10,000 eligible Australian households each year.
For states to participate, legislation will need to be passed for the scheme to operate in their jurisdiction. All states have agreed to progress legislation so the scheme will run nationally.

The Home Guarantee Scheme (the Scheme) gives eligible first home buyers and single parents support to purchase a home sooner by reducing the deposit they need to save to buy a house. The Scheme is administered by Housing Australia on behalf of the Albanese Government.
The Scheme includes:
The First Home Guarantee—to support eligible first home buyers to buy their first home sooner, with a deposit as little as 5 per cent. 35,000 places are available each financial year;

The Regional First Home Buyer Guarantee—to support eligible regional first home buyers to buy a home in a regional area. From 1 October 2022, 10,000 places are available each financial year to 30 June 2025; and

The Family Home Guarantee—to support eligible single parents with at least one dependent child to buy a home, with a deposit as little as 2 per cent. 5,000 places are available each financial year to 30 June 2025.
On 1 July 2023, the Albanese Government expanded the eligibility of the Home Guarantee Scheme to help more Australians purchase a home sooner:

Under the First Home Guarantee and Regional First Home Buyer Guarantee, any two eligible borrowers can jointly apply, not just spouses or de facto couples. Non-first home buyers who have not held a property interest in Australia within the previous 10 years will also be eligible for both guarantees.
The Family Home Guarantee was expanded to include single legal guardians of children.
All guarantees are available to Australian permanent residents.

More than 73,000 people have been helped into home ownership since the election of the Albanese Government through the Home Guarantee Scheme, including more than 10,000 through the Regional First Home Buyer Guarantee. The scheme has now been expanded significantly—the changes will see friends, siblings, and other family members eligible for joint applications under the First Home Guarantee and the Regional First Home Buyer Guarantee.

We've also established a National Housing Supply and Affordability Council to provide expert advice and an evidence base on how Government can improve housing supply and affordability, and legislation has passed the Parliament to create the Council as a permanent independent body.

As you can see, the Albanese Government's ambitious housing reform agenda is designed to boost supply, increase housing affordability and make positive and practical differences for Australians planning to buy a home.
We are doing this to make sure more Australians have an affordable place to call home.
The Albanese Government has added to its broad housing agenda at every opportunity.
It's a plan we are proud of and after a decade of little action we are working hard to turn around the housing challenges in Australia today.
Once again thank you for taking the time to write to me. I hope the information provided is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing, Ms Collins
Diesel
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4179 on lowering the price of diesel fuel to better match the price of unleaded fuel. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Government recognises that the cost of fuel is putting family and business budgets under significant pressure and driving up the price of essentials like groceries. It remains critical that fuel companies promptly pass on reductions in international oil prices.
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) is responsible for monitoring fuel prices and plays a critical role in ensuring that market participants do not take advantage of consumers.

The ACCC's Report on the Australian Petroleum market for the June 2023 quarter found that diesel prices were significantly higher than petrol prices for several reasons. International prices for diesel were higher than for petrol, driven by reduced supply from Russia given the conflict in Ukraine, reduced supply from France due to refinery strikes, reduced exports from China, low global stocks and higher demand for diesel for heating during the northern hemisphere winter. Diesel, unlike petrol, has broader uses in industry and electricity generation that affect demand and therefore price.

The ACCC has found that, in recent months, the prices of diesel and petrol have converged with the price of diesel dipping lower than petrol. The decrease in diesel prices has been influenced by continuing exports from Russia despite sanctions imposed by the United States, reduced diesel consumption due to decreased manufacturing and freight activity in North America and Europe, and an unexpected build up in global diesel inventories.

As the independent regulator enforcing Australia's competition and consumer laws, the ACCC investigates concerns arising about misrepresentations regarding fuel prices, and false and misleading conduct or anti-competitive conduct in fuel markets and takes appropriate action. In addition, the ACCC is engaging with major retailers and wholesalers to ensure that they do not mislead Australian consumers about the rationale for any price rises.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Banking and Financial Services
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4244 regarding a moratorium on regional bank closures and the establishment of a Parliamentary inquiry. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

I understand that branch closures are disruptive for customers in regional and rural areas, particularly for those experiencing vulnerability. I am also sorry to hear about the difficulties people are facing with regard to access to banking services.

Amid the increasing availability of banking alternatives like telephone, online and mobile app banking, there has been a decline in over-the-counter transactions and a shift to online activity. These shifts in consumer demand and new technologies have contributed to banks reducing their branch networks.

The Albanese Government is concerned about the impact of these developments on communities who need access to face-to-face banking services, as well as on small businesses that need to access and deposit cash.

Australia Post's Bank@Post service is part of the solution. Through this service, customers can make withdrawals, deposits and balance enquiries at their local Post Office. Currently, over 3,500 Post Offices are providing access to more than 80 banks and financial institutions. This includes more than 1,800 Bank@Post offices in rural and remote locations.

Initiated in February 2023, the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee is currently examining the impact of regional bank branch closures. The Government will consider the findings of this inquiry after the Senate Committee issues its final report by May 2024. Further information about the inquiry can be found at: www.aph.gov.au.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Jones
Taxation
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4259 on previously announced changes to the Australian individual tax residency rules. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

As you may know, the former Government announced in the 2021-22 Budget that it would replace the individual tax residency rules with a new, modernised framework. The proposed framework was based on the model recommended by the Board of Taxation (the Board) in its 2019 report: Individual Tax Residency Rules—a model for modernisation (the 2019 report).

The Government publicly consulted for 9 weeks ending 22 September 2023 on the proposed new individual tax residency framework. This consultation process provided stakeholders with an opportunity to express their views and the outcomes of consultation will help to inform the Government's decision on whether to proceed with reform of the individual tax residency rules.
I can assure you that the views put forward in submissions to the consultation will receive careful consideration.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Jones
Nuclear Energy
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 25 July 2023 regarding petition EN4269 concerning nuclear energy. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.
