The Australian Government has no plans to change the longstanding moratorium on nuclear power in Australia, which is prohibited by law under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.

The high cost and long deployment time of nuclear power makes it an unviable choice for Australia. The GenCost 2022-23 Report, prepared by the CSIRO and the Australian Energy Market Operator (AEMO), shows that renewables are the cheapest form of generation for Australia, even when additional costs for storage and new transmission are included.
Renewable technologies are quicker to build and cheaper to operate.

Putting downwards pressure on electricity prices is why we are focused on transforming our electricity system so that more renewable energy powers our homes. Under the Rewiring the Nation policy, we are investing $20 billion to expand and upgrade our electricity grid to ensure it can support the boost needed in cheap and reliable renewable energy generation. In addition, we are investing in the Capacity Investment Scheme, which will deliver at least 6 GW of dispatchable renewable energy, boosting reliability and putting downward pressure on prices. We are also investing $100 million in solar banks and $200 million in new community batteries to help more people access solar and maximise the benefits of Australia's energy transformation.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of this petition to my attention.
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Nuclear Energy
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 25 July 2023 regarding petition EN4278 to consider nuclear power for Australia. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Australian Government has no plans to change the longstanding moratorium on nuclear power in Australia, which is prohibited by law under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.

The high cost and long deployment time of nuclear power makes it an unviable choice for Australia. The GenCost 2022-23 Report, prepared by the CSIRO and the Australian Energy Market Operator (AEMO), shows that renewables are the cheapest form of generation for Australia, even when additional costs for storage and new transmission are included.
Renewable technologies are quicker to build and cheaper to operate.

Putting downwards pressure on electricity prices is why we are focused on transforming our electricity system so that more renewable energy powers our homes. Under the Rewiring the Nation policy, we are investing $20 billion to upgrade our electricity grid to ensure it can support the boost needed in renewable energy generation. In addition, we are investing in the Capacity Investment Scheme, which will deliver at least 6 GW of dispatchable capacity, boosting reliability and putting downward pressure on prices. We are also investing $100 million in solar banks and $200 million in new community batteries to help more people access solar and maximise the benefits of Australia's energy transformation.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of this petition to my attention.
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Housing
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4283 on the utilisation of unoccupied housing for those suffering from homelessness, poverty and general malaise from lack of rental properties. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Albanese Labor Government understands safe and affordable housing is central to the security and dignity of all Australians. Sadly, many Australians cannot find an affordable place to buy, rising interest rates have been difficult news for those with a mortgage and the rental market is also very tight with low vacancy rates and increasing rents across Australia.

The Albanese Government has committed to an ambitious housing reform agenda which will boost the supply of all housing—more public and social housing, more affordable housing, more homes to rent and more homes to buy.
These housing challenges cannot be solved by one government alone. The Albanese Government is working with the state, territory and local governments to deliver better housing outcomes.
This includes the work being delivered through the National Cabinet to provide more secure and affordable housing supply. Significant measures include:

The National Housing Accord that will support planning and zoning reforms, as well as investing $350 million in additional federal funding to deliver 10,000 affordable rental homes over five years from 2024—matched by the state and territories.
Federal funding of $2 billion through the Social Housing Accelerator to deliver thousands of social homes across Australia.

Federal funding of $3 billion through the New Homes Bonus to help incentivise states and territories to build more homes where people need them to meet a new national target of 1.2 million new homes over five years.

A $500 million Housing Support Program for initiatives to help kick start housing supply including connecting essential services, amenities to support new housing development or building planning capability.
A National Planning Reform Blueprint with planning, zoning, land release and other measures to improve housing supply and affordability.
A Better Deal for Renters to harmonise and strengthen renters' rights across Australia.
These measures are in addition to the work that is being delivered.
In addition, legislation to establish the $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund to support 30,000 new social and affordable rental homes over its first five years has now passed the Parliament.

We are working with states and territories to deliver the Help to Buy Scheme, supporting up to 40,000 low and middle income households to purchase a home of their own. This will bring home ownership back into reach for thousands of Australians who have been locked out of the housing market.

The National Housing Infrastructure Facility (NHIF) has been expanded making up to $575 million available to invest in social and affordable rental homes, with projects already under construction as a result of this funding. The NHIF will also receive an additional $1 billion of federal funding to support more social housing.

The National Housing Finance and Investment Corporation's liability cap has been increased by $2 billion to provide lower cost and longer-term finance to community housing providers through the Affordable Housing Bond Aggregator.
The largest increase to Commonwealth Rent Assistance in more than 30 years is being provided, with a 15 per cent increase in the maximum rates.
Tax incentives are being introduced to encourage more build-to-rent developments to boost new supply in the private rental market.

Federal funding of $1.7 billion has been provided for a one-year extension of the National Housing and Homelessness Agreement with States and Territories, including a $67.5 million boost to homelessness funding over the next year.
Work to deliver on a new National Housing and Homelessness Plan is happening to identify the short, medium, and long-term steps that can be taken to address housing issues in Australia.

More than 73,000 Australians have been helped into home ownership through the Home Guarantee Scheme, including more than 10,000 through the Regional First Home Buyer Guarantee. The scheme has now been expanded significantly—changes will see friends, siblings, and other family members eligible for joint applications under the First Home Guarantee and the Regional First Home Buyer Guarantee.

We've also established an interim National Housing Supply and Affordability Council to provide expert advice and an evidence base on how Government can improve housing supply and affordability, while legislation goes through the Parliament to create the Council as an independent body.

As you can see, the Albanese Government's ambitious housing reform agenda is designed to boost supply, increase housing affordability and make positive and practical differences for Australians planning to buy a home.
We are doing this to make sure more Australians have an affordable place to call home.
The Albanese Government has added to its broad housing agenda at every opportunity.
It's a plan we are proud of and after a decade of inaction we are working hard to turn around the housing challenges in Australia today.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing, Ms Collins
Economy
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4297 regarding price gouging. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Government recognises that the increasing cost of living is putting pressure on household budgets, driven by a range of factors including international factors and shortages in important commodities.
The Albanese Government's number one priority remains addressing this inflation and cost of living challenge.
The Government has a targeted and comprehensive $23 billion ten-point plan to help address the cost of living pressures in our economy -
1. Electricity bill relief
2. Cheaper child care
3. Increased rent assistance
4. More Medicare bulk billing
5. Cheaper medicines
6. Boosting income support payments
7. Fee-free TAFE training
8. Building more affordable homes
9. Expanding paid parental leave and
10. Creating jobs and getting wages moving again

Australia's competition laws prohibit anti-competitive conduct, such as price collusion, by businesses. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) is responsible for enforcing these laws.

If a business makes misleading claims about the reason for price increases, it will likely be breaching the Australian Consumer Law (ACL). In some circumstances, excessive pricing may be considered unconscionable where it is extreme and targets particularly vulnerable consumers.

If the ACCC finds evidence of breaches of the ACL they have a powerful toolkit to investigate and take action through the courts where appropriate. The ACCC can be contacted on 1300 302 502 or via its website at: www.accc.gov.au.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Migration: Bangladesh
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for the correspondence of 31 July 2023 from the Secretariat Standing Committee on Petitions, enclosing Petition EN4315, with two (2) signatures, presented in the House on 7 November 2022, concerning offshore student visa processing matters for Bangladesh nationals. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

I understand the petitioners' concerns around the low percentage of offshore student visas granted to Bangladesh nationals in 2020 compared to other top source countries. It is no secret that the international travel restrictions in place (from March 2020 through to December 2021) due to the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted the offshore student visa activity (lodged and subsequently finalised) and affected all nationalities including Bangladesh.
I would like to use this opportunity to advise that, from 2005-06 (when reports become available) to 2022-23 for the primary offshore student visa caseload:

Bangladesh nationals represented an average 1 per cent of total visa granted. This is attributed to Bangladesh representing only 1.1 per cent (average) of student visa applications submitted to the Department of Home Affairs; and

Between 2017-18 (when the Department ceased offshore student visa processing in Bangladesh) and 2022-23, average grant rate for Bangladesh nationals was 90.3 per cent. This is a 15.7 per cent improvement compared to the average grant rate (74.6 per cent) between 2005-06 and 2016-17. (Data source: Department of Home Affairs and published at https://data.gov.au/data/dataset/student-visas).

The change in student visa processing arrangements has not adversely impacted decision outcomes for Bangladeshi student visa applicants. As always, applications are assessed on their individual merits against the regulatory criteria prescribed in Australia's migration legislation. These criteria apply universally irrespective of the student visa applicant's nationality and/or the location where the visa application is processed.

Further, I wish to advise the committee that the Department continues to monitor visa decision outcomes through a robust program of quality assurance. The Department samples and examines the decisions and decision making process applied to cases across our network, ensuring that appropriate compliance with the legislation is maintained.

I appreciate the petitioners' request to reestablish student visa processing arrangements in Bangladesh. It is however imperative that decisions made to establish an offshore presence must be balanced against our focus on efficient, cost effective services which enhance our ability to uphold the integrity of Australia's visa programs in general, including for student visas.

The Government is not considering the reestablishment of visa processing arrangements in Bangladesh. I do however welcome more Bangladesh nationals to consider Australia's international student visa program to study and enhance their skills while also contributing to the Australian workforce and Australian society.
The following resources provided by the Department may be of assistance for student visa applicants, including from Bangladesh:
'Check twice, submit once' at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/check-twice- submit-once
'What to do if you didn't get a Student visa to Australia'. Tips to improve your application on the Department's social media pages at:
Facebook: http://spr.ly/60033974S
LinkedIn: http://spr.ly/6009397AP
'Who can help you with your application' at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/help-support/who-can-help-with-your-application
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4315 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Nuclear Energy
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 25 July 2023 regarding petition EN4387 to remove the prohibition of nuclear power. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Australian Government has no plans to change the longstanding moratorium on nuclear power in Australia, which is prohibited by law under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.

The high cost and long deployment time of nuclear power makes it an unviable choice for Australia. The GenCost 2022-23 Report, prepared by the CSIRO and the Australian Energy Market Operator (AEMO), shows that renewables are the cheapest form of generation for Australia, even when additional costs for storage and new transmission are included. Renewable technologies are quicker to build and cheaper to operate.

Putting downwards pressure on electricity prices is why we are focused on transforming our electricity system so that more renewable energy powers our homes. Under the Rewiring the Nation policy, we are investing $20 billion to upgrade our electricity grid to ensure it can support the boost needed in renewable energy generation. In addition, we are investing in the Capacity Investment Scheme, which will deliver at least 6 GW of dispatchable capacity, boosting reliability and putting downward pressure on prices. We are also investing $100 million in solar banks and $200 million in new community batteries to help more people access solar and maximise the benefits of Australia's energy transformation.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Youth Justice
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence received on 25 July 2023, regarding a petition presented in the House of Representatives on 7 November 2022 (EN4390) related to raising the minimum age of criminal responsibility.

I am pleased to note that several jurisdictions have made progress on raising the minimum age of criminal responsibility including the Northern Territory, Australian Capital Territory and Victoria. While State and Territory governments are responsible for the administration of youth justice systems, the Australian Government is playing a leadership role in working with the States and Territories on this issue through the Standing Council of Attorneys-General (SCAG).

In August 2022 I put the minimum age of criminal responsibility on the SCAG agenda and all participants agreed to reconvene the Age of Criminal Responsibility Working Group (the Working Group) to continue to develop a proposal to increase the minimum age of criminal responsibility in Australia, paying particular attention to eliminating the overrepresentation of First Nations' children in the criminal justice system. At the December 2022 SCAG, Attorneys-General agreed to release a draft report on the minimum age of criminal responsibility prepared by a previous iteration of the Working Group for the then Council of Attorneys-General in 2020. The report was not agreed to by all jurisdictions, nor was it provided to the Council of Attorneys-General for consideration.

The reconvened Working Group has been considering complex issues associated with raising the age, including exploring alternative therapeutic service system design, and ensuring there are mechanisms in place to adequately support children who are diverted away from the criminal justice system. The Working Group delivered a report on this work to SCAG at its meeting on 22 September 2023. The Government is considering the report.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Parliamentary Standards
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email of 7 November 2022 to me regarding a petition relating to drug and alcohol testing for Members of Parliament (Petition number EN4408).

The President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives have responsibility for the good order of Senators and Members of the House, and ensuring that laws are observed in the Parliamentary precinct.
Ultimately, the decision to implement drug and alcohol testing for parliamentarians would be a decision for each chamber of the Parliament to consider.

The petitioners may be interested to know that the Government is committed to working across the Parliament to implement all 28 recommendations of the Australian Human Rights Commission's Set the Standard: Report on the Independent Review into Commonwealth Parliamentary Workplaces. Implementation of the Report's recommendations is a shared responsibility across the Parliament.

One of those recommendations is that consistent and comprehensive alcohol policies be implemented across Commonwealth parliamentary workplaces with a view to restricting availability in line with work health and safety obligations and the principle of harm minimisation.

Work is underway to respond to that recommendation. More about progress in implementing the Set the Standard Report on the Parliamentary Leadership Taskforce's website:
.https://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/Parliamentary_Leadership_Taskforce
Thank you again for bringing this issue to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, Mr Gorman
Sport: Australian Football League
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 regarding a petition around funding to support the development of gender-neutral amenities at AFL and AFLW playing grounds and venues. I understand there was a technical error in transmitting this correspondence to the Government.

The Albanese Labor Government provides strong support to local sporting clubs across Australia which helps to improve their sporting infrastructure. This investment in sport encourages more Australians to get involved in sport and physical activity, brings communities together, boosts the economy and supports our elite athletes to pursue sporting success on the global stage.

Additionally, on 19 August 2023, the Australian Government announced the $200 million 'Play Our Way' program to improve sporting facilities and equipment specifically for women and girls. Play Our Way will promote equal access, build more suitable facilities, and support grassroots initiatives to get women and girls to engage, stay, and participate in sport throughout their lives.

On this basis, I acknowledge this petition and I also acknowledge that the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, the Hon Catherine King MP, has responsibility for infrastructure under her portfolio. I have copied Minister King into this response.
cc: The Hon Catherine King MP, Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Sport, Ms Wells(Petition No. EN4440)
Defence Procurement: Submarines
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 8 November 2022 regarding the petition EN4473 to name a nuclear submarine after former Prime Minister Harold Edward Holt CH.

The Royal Australian Navy's ship and submarine naming process is well established and places a strong emphasis on promoting links between the Navy and the Australian community, reflecting a uniquely Australian identity.

The Chief of Navy and I receive many requests to name new Royal Australian Navy vessels, normally after cities, towns and regions of Australia. This reinforces the great respect that communities, ex-service groups and individuals have for the Navy.

Reviewing these numerous requests is an integral part of the naming process and I can assure you all representations receive careful consideration. The process examines many aspects including history, community expectations and the need to balance representation from across Australia. The submission will be considered as part of the process, though I note the Naval Communications Station in Western Australia is already named Harold E Holt in recognition of our former Prime Minister.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Marles
Australian Curriculum
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 6 February 2023 regarding Petition Ministerial Referral number EN4600.

The Australian Government considers language education an important part of a student's education, celebrating Australia's multicultural society. The Australian Curriculum, which sets high expectations and standards for what all students should know and be able to do, underwent a comprehensive review in 2021, and was endorsed by all state and territory governments in April 2022. This review included consultation on the Languages learning area, which resulted in a more streamlined language curriculum. As such, there are no current plans to add more languages into the Australian Curriculum at this stage. Further information on the updated Australian Curriculum is available at www.v9.australiancurriculum.edu.au.

While the Australian Government plays a national leadership role in school education, under the Australian Constitution, state and territory government and non-government education authorities are responsible for the implementation of the Curriculum within their jurisdictions, including determining which languages are taught within their schools.

While Punjabi is not one of 14 languages taught under the Australian Curriculum, jurisdictions may still choose to add Punjabi to their state-based curriculum or school language programs, as is the case in New South Wales. Further information is available at www.educationstandards.nsw.edu.au. The petitioner may wish to contact their state or territory Education Minister to discuss their addition of Punjabi to the jurisdiction's school curriculum.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare
First Nations Australians: Child Protection
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email of 6 February 2023 about A Safer Future for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children petition (EN4648). As the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities, the petition and your email have been forwarded to me.

The Australian Government acknowledges the petition for a safer future for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children, and that children and young people in Australia have the right to grow up safe, connected and supported in their family, community and culture. They have the right to grow up in an environment that enables them to reach their full potential.

Safe and Supported: the National Framework for Protecting Australia's Children
2021-2031 (Safe and Supported) recognises that all Australians need to work together to keep children and young people safe and achieve the best outcomes for those who are vulnerable and/or experiencing disadvantage. Safe and Supported and its Action Plans were developed by the Australian Government and state and territory governments in partnership with SNAICC-National Voice for our Children (SNAICC) and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Leadership Group (Leadership Group).

Action 7 of Safe and Supported: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander First Action Plan 2023-2026 (Action Plan) commits to establishing and strengthening Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commissioner and similar roles. As part of the 2022-23 Federal Budget, $2 million over 4 years (2022-23 to 2025-26) was committed to establish a National Advocate for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children and Young People (National Advocate). This measure sits under Action 7, activity c in the Action Plan.

The department acknowledges the calls from SNAICC and the Leadership Group to elevate the National Advocate role to a National Commissioner for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children and young people. The department is working with SNAICC, the Leadership Group, members of the Early Childhood Care and Development Policy Partnership and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children's Commissioners, Guardians and Advocates to progress Action 7.

The first of two workshops to explore how to strengthen government accountability and elevate the voices of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children and Young People was held on 11 September 2023. The next workshop is scheduled for 17 November 2023.

Additional work to support the establishment of Commissioners or similar roles in jurisdictions includes the development of Minimum Standards for National, State and Territory Commissioners for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children and young people (Action 7a).
If you would like any further information regarding Safe and Supported, please contact National.Framework@dss.gov.au.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth

subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice

p.span: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 20 March 2023 referring petition EN4769 about the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice referendum. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The referendum is about the principle of recognising First Nations people in the Constitution through establishing a Voice. The Voice design principles provide a framework for the development of the Voice. After a successful referendum, the Government would commence a process to design the Voice including consultation through a Joint Parliamentary Committee co-chaired by the Government and the Opposition. The Voice's composition, functions, powers and procedures will be a matter for the Parliament to legislate. Leaving the specifics to legislation would ensure the Voice is able to evolve and adapt as circumstances change.

The referendum question and constitutional amendment were introduced into Parliament through the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) Bill 2023 on 30 March 2023. A Joint Parliamentary Committee Inquiry, which included consideration of public submissions, recommended the Bill pass without amendment. The Committee was provided with a submission from the Attorney-General, the Hon Mark Dreyfus KC MP. This submission contained advice from the Solicitor-General, which stated that "the proposed amendment is not only compatible with the system of representative and responsible government established under the Constitution, but it enhances that system".

The Bill was passed without amendment on 19 June 2023. If passed on 14 October 2023, the referendum would insert a new section, section 129, into the Constitution. I have enclosed a copy of the referendum question and proposed constitutional amendment.

There has been over a decade of discussion and consultation about constitutional recognition, driven by the efforts of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. This process has included expert panels, parliamentary committees, the Kirribilli Statement, the publication of the Uluru Statement from the Heart following the conclusion of the Uluru Dialogues, and the Indigenous Voice Co-design process.

The Government undertook significant consultation when developing the Bill, including consultation with constitutional experts. Following this robust consultation process, changes were made to the draft constitutional provision, including to make clear the primacy of Parliament.
Thank you for raising this matter.

Encl (1) Design Principles of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice; (2) Fact Sheet—Referendum Question and Constitutional Amendment; (3) Opinion of the Solicitor- General, SG No. 10 of 2023
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Indigenous Australians, Ms Burney
Electric Vehicles
Dear Chair

Thank you for referring a copy of petition EN4880 presented to the House of Representatives on 9 May 2023 regarding providing financial incentives for Australians to convert internal combustion engines (ICE) of existing vehicles to electric motors. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

I appreciate the idea of providing financial incentives to convert existing ICE cars into electric cars, however, my Department advises retrofitting ICE vehicles to electric cars is not cost- effective as it involves the replacement of several vehicle components, and requires a range of safety and training issues to be addressed.

The Australian Government has already announced a range of initiatives to support the uptake of EVs including the Electric Car Discount that reduces the upfront costs associated with purchasing an EV. The Government's $500 million Driving the Nation Fund more than doubles the Commonwealth's investment in EV charging and hydrogen refuelling infrastructure, including in regional and remote parts of the country.

In April 2023, the Government released its first National Electric Vehicle Strategy. The Strategy provides a nationally consistent, comprehensive framework to consider supply, demand, and infrastructure needs for cleaner and cheaper vehicles in Australia.

At the heart of the Strategy is the Government's commitment to introduce a fuel efficiency standard. Introducing a mandatory light vehicle fuel efficiency standard will encourage car manufacturers to supply more electric vehicles and low emission vehicles to Australia, improving consumer choice and making it easier and cheaper to access popular electric vehicle models. Over time, a fuel efficiency standard will also help make all vehicles on the road more efficient, with new petrol and diesel cars likely to use less fuel, saving Australians money and reducing emissions.

The Government is committed to ensuring that design of the fuel efficiency standard balances emissions reductions with economic benefits. The Government is currently considering the input from more than 2,500 submissions that were received as part of consultation on fuel efficiency standards undertaken by the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development, Communications and the Arts.

A fuel efficiency standard will require fresh legislation to be put to the Australian Parliament. The Government is aiming to release an Impact Analysis in the coming months and a proposed fuel efficiency standard model by the end of 2023.
Thank you again for bringing your concerns to the Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Pakistan: State Elections
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter containing petition EN4979 expressing concern about the state of democracy in Pakistan and the timing of elections in Punjab and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa provinces. While the timing of elections in Pakistan is a matter for relevant Pakistan authorities, we encourage Pakistan to conduct timely elections that are free, fair and credible and in accordance with the constitution.

The Australian Government continues to call for all parties to adhere to the rule of law and to respect and promote human rights for all. We regularly engages with all sides of politics, including through our High Commission in Pakistan. The Australian Government regularly raises human rights directly with the Government of Pakistan, including to underscore the importance of freedom of expression and of association, foster tolerance, and strengthen civil society and its institutions. We also continue to raise our concerns internationally, including at the United Nations Human Rights Council.
The Australian High Commission in Islamabad continues to closely monitor developments in Pakistan.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Refugee and Humanitarian Program: Afghanistan
Dear Ms Susan Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 19 June 2023 concerning Australia's Humanitarian Program. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is committed to compassionate and flexible Humanitarian and Settlement Programs that meet Australia's international protection obligations and position Australia as a global leader in international resettlement efforts.

To ensure Australia continues to play its part, the Government will work closely with both the international and domestic community, particularly the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), as we deliver Australia's humanitarian intake
Consistent with the approach adopted by the UNHCR, Australia will prioritise those cohorts who have the greatest resettlement need.

Any person who believes they meet the requirements for a humanitarian visa and wishes to seek Australia's assistance can make an application. All applications are assessed on an individual basis with applicants required to demonstrate their humanitarian need. Further information on how to apply can be found on the Department of Home Affairs website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/what-we-do/refugee-and-humanitarian-program/about-the-program/resettle-in-australia.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5031 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Skilled Migration
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 20 June 2023 regarding Petition (EN5055).

The Australian Government is committed to delivering a migration system that facilitates high rates of workforce participation, boosting the economy and filling skills and labour shortages in priority occupations.

The requirements for the grant of a visa are set out in the Migration Act 1958 and the Migration Regulations 1994. All visa applicants must satisfy the relevant legislative provisions for the grant of the visa, including where necessary, a suitable skills assessment not more than three years old. This timeframe provides for currency of skills assessments in accordance with industry standards.

In my capacity as the Minister for Skills and Training, I appoint assessing authorities under the Migration Regulations 1994 to undertake skills assessments for occupations on the Skilled Migration Occupation Lists. Trades Recognition Australia (TRA) within the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations, is appointed as an assessing authority for people with trade skills gained overseas or in Australia.

The Job Ready Program, administered by TRA, delivers a 12-month employment-based skills assessment that provides participants with the opportunity to develop skills associated with their nominated occupation and gain valuable employment experience in an Australian workplace. It provides a skills assessment outcome that participants can use to apply to the Department of Home Affairs for a skilled visa. Where applicants have been working in their occupation for at least 3 years (full-time or equivalent) and require an updated skills assessment, they can apply through the Migrant Skills Assessment Program. This skills assessment costs $795 and entails a streamlined documentary evidence check.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Skills and Training, Mr O'Connor

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Constitution: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice

p.span: Australian Constitution: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 21 June 2023 referring petition EN5059 about the referendum on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The 2023 referendum will give us the opportunity to recognise Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians in our Constitution through a Voice. The Government is committed to holding the referendum to allow Australians to vote on this significant reform.

On 19 June 2023 the Parliament passed the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) Bill 2023 without amendment. The Bill has paved the way for a referendum to be held in accordance with section 128 of the Constitution.

On 11 September 2023, the Governor-General, General David Hurley issued a writ to the Australian Electoral Commissioner, Mr Tom Rodgers instructing the Australian Electoral Commission to hold a referendum on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice on 14 October 2023.

The Bill has been extensively scrutinised by some of the best legal minds in the country, including the Constitutional Expert Group and the Solicitor-General, Dr Stephen Donaghue KC. The Solicitor-General has advised that The Voice is 'not just compatible with the system of representative and responsible government prescribed by the Constitution, but an enhancement of that system'.

There are currently 11 First Nations Members of Parliament and Senators. However, there is no guarantee this will remain the same in the next term or the term after that. Structural change is needed to ensure First Nations people are always heard on the policies that affect them, which will lead to better outcomes. A constitutionally enshrined Voice provides a permanent means of providing advice to the Parliament and the Government.

The Constitutional Expert Group advising Government has made clear the Voice will be an advisory body and will not provide special rights to First Nations people, nor would it change or remove any rights, powers or privileges of anyone who is not Indigenous. The Voice will not come at the expense of cost-of-living relief.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Indigenous Australians, Ms Burney
Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 20 June 2023 regarding petition EN5091 on the Australian Government's decision to increase maximum dispensing quantities for some medications listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).

Australian pharmacies already do much more than just dispense medicines, and the Government wants our trusted pharmacists to play an even bigger role in the healthcare of Australians. That is why every dollar saved by the Government through fewer dispensing payments will be re-invested back into community pharmacy, to support these highly trained professionals to deliver expanded services, and better recognise pharmacists' scope of practice.

This reinvestment will go towards increasing the total budget for Community Pharmacy Programs under the Seventh Community Pharmacy Agreement from $1.2 billion to $1.4 billion. Already, as part of the 2023-24 Budget, the Government has ensured patients will have continued access to medication management and dose administration aids with funding for community pharmacy programs increased ($654.9 million over four years).

Additionally, the money saved will be invested to fund a nationally consistent Opioid Dependence Treatment Program ($377.3 million over four years), which commenced on 1 July 2023, and means these patients now only pay the relevant PBS co-payment for these medicines. This funding is in addition to the funding pharmacists will receive for dispensing these medicines on the PBS under the Section 100 Highly Specialised Drugs Community Access Program. The Government estimates participating pharmacists will receive between $175 to $191 per patient per month under these new arrangements.

The Government will also expand funding for pharmacists to administer vaccines under the National Immunisation Program ($114.1 million over four years). From 1 January 2024, pharmacists will receive a payment of $18.85 per vaccine administered at no cost to the patient—the same amount a GP receives for a Level A Consultation for this same service.

Pharmacy stakeholders have asked successive Governments for remuneration of these services to be at the same level as GPs. This initiative replaces current vaccination services where patients' need to self-fund the service. Vaccines that can be administered by a pharmacist are determined by relevant state and territory legislation.

Further support is also being made available to pharmacies in regional, rural, and remote Australia through the doubling of the budget for the Regional Pharmacy Maintenance Allowance from 1 July 2023. This is expected to mean a significant increase in funding for over 1,000 community pharmacies in regional, rural and remote areas across Australia ($79.5 million over four years).

The Government has also recently announced further support for regional, rural and remote pharmacies with the introduction of the Regional Pharmacy Transition Allowance ($148.2 million over four years) to assist pharmacies in transitioning their business arrangement to adapt to maximum dispensing quantities. When considered in conjunction with the Regional Pharmacy Maintenance Allowance, the total assistance of these two programs is expected to mean that eligible pharmacies in Monash Model 3-7 locations will, on average, largely have dispensing related remuneration reductions due to implementation of the 60-Day dispensing policy, mostly offset in 2023-24.

The Department of Health and Aged Care acknowledges the modelling commissioned by the Pharmacy Guild of Australia in relation to the 60-day dispensing reforms. The report suggests that at least 665 pharmacies will close across Australia. This is based on a 'Central Scenario' with uptake ranging from 63% in 2023-24 to 90% in 2026-27. Department modelling has uptake ranging from 45% in 2023-24 to 63% in 2026-27.

This central scenario modelling from Ergas suggests a significantly more aggressive uptake of 60 Day dispensing. The central scenario modelled by Ergas suggests a reduction in dispensing related remuneration of $4.5 billion over four years (Government and patient combined). This is 1.5 times higher than the Government modelled costs of $3 billion over four years (Government and patient combined). The report also includes a reduction in other retail sales estimated to be around, on average, $20. Retail sales are independent to Government remuneration for dispensing related activities.

We understand that pharmacies are profit-making businesses, and they have to consider their bottom line. The Government is committed to a vibrant community pharmacy sector in Australia, with a growing role for pharmacy in primary healthcare, and will continue to consider options available to it to support community pharmacy as they transition their business arrangements to account for this new policy.

Finally, as announced on 7 August 2023, negotiations for the Eight Community Pharmacy Agreement (8CPA) will soon commence. The 8CPA will support patient access to Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) subsidised medicines, programs, and related services through community pharmacies across Australia. Negotiations will commence as soon as possible and are expected to conclude by 30 June 2024.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Skilled Migration
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 20 June 2023 enclosing Petition EN5093, with 265 signatures, concerning the increase to the Temporary Skilled Migration Income Threshold (TSMIT).
On 27 April 2023 I announced that the TSMIT would be raised to $70,000 from 1 July 2023. The increase in TSMIT took effect from 1 July 2023.

The TSMIT applies to key employer sponsored visas: the Temporary Skill Shortage (subclass 482) visa, the Skilled Employer Sponsored Regional (subclass 494) visa, the Employer Nomination Scheme (subclass 186) visa, and the Regional Sponsored Migration Scheme (subclass 187) visa. Sponsoring employers in these programs are required to pay the higher of the TSMIT or the annual market salary rate for the skilled position they nominate to be filled with a worker from overseas.

This is the first increase to the TSMIT since 2013. The new $70,000 income threshold is approximately where the TSMIT would have been if it had been indexed to average weekly ordinary time earnings growth over the previous 10 years. Increasing the TSMIT ensures that our skilled visa programs are targeted at highly skilled workers who are less open to exploitation. It is also intended b ensure migrants entering Australia under these programs have sufficient income to support themselves and their families, noting that temporary migrants have limited or no access to social security payments and face a higher cost of living than Australians.

The Australian Government acknowledges the increase may raise concerns in some sectors and in regional Australia, however, the new TSMIT income threshold appropriately reflects growth in Australian wages since it was last adjusted in 2013.

The petition is particularly concerned with the effect of a changed TSMIT on applicants for Skilled Work Regional (Provisional) (subclass 491) visas and the pathway to permanent residence for holders of those visas. Eligible holders of subclass 491 visas and Skilled Employer Sponsored Regional (Provisional) (subclass 494) visas have a pathway to the Permanent Residence (Skilled Regional) (subclass 191) visa in the Regional Provisional Stream.

There has been no change to the income requirement for the subclass 191 visa. However, advice on the website of the Department of Home Affairs has been updated to clarify the requirements of the subclass 191 visa including:
Although there is no legislative instrument in place specifying a minimum income threshold for this visa, under policy the income of holders of a:

subclass 491 visa is assessed against Federal and industrial wage requirements ensuring they are paid at least the same as an equivalent Australian worker applying either the annual market salary rate or industrial award whichever applies in their circumstance, and
subclass 494 visa are assessed against the TSMIT, and
Primary applicants must provide notices of assessment issued by the Australian Taxation Office for three income years out of the five years of their eligible visa.

The Review of Australia's Migration System suggested the Government consider migration solutions for cohorts paid below TSM IT. This included consideration of tripartite engagement between unions, business and government to reduce the risk of exploitation and displacing similarly skilled Australian workers. The Government is currently considering recommendations.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5093 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neil
Australian Taxation Office
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5111 on investment property loan data-matching. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) collects personal information about taxpayers for the purposes of administering the tax and superannuation systems. When the ATO collects personal information about taxpayers, they are required by law to advise taxpayers that the ATO has collected the information and why they have done so.

The residential investment property loan data-matching program is part of a broader suite of data-matching programs that allow the ATO to address several taxation risks in the investment property market. The tax gap for rental income is estimated to be $1.3 billion, and ATO observations indicate that incorrect apportionment of the loan interest costs are a significant driver of this gap.
To keep the data safe, data-matching programs conducted by the ATO comply with the requirements of the:
the Privacy Act 1988 (Privacy Act) and the Australian Privacy Principles within the Privacy Act
Australian Government Information Security Manual which governs the security of government information and communication technology (ICT) systems
Australian Government Protective Security Policy Framework which provides guidance on security governance, personnel security, physical security and information security.

Further information on the residential investment property loan data-matching program, including how the ATO protects this data and the personal information received can be found on their website, www.ato.gov.au, by inserting 'QC 72074' into the website's search function.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Jones
Air Safety
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 1 August 2023 presenting Petition EN5115—Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena {UAP). I have considered the matters raised in the petition.

I note the petition requests the House conduct a formal review of UAP to consider the establishment of an investigatory body to assess the potential national security threats and safety of flight risks that UAP pose.

As acknowledged in the petition, Defence ceased handling reports of UAP in 1996 as there was no scientific or compelling reason to continue to divert resources to the recording and investigation of UAP. Defence does maintain robust safety and security reporting and management frameworks that are sufficiently flexible to capture UAP.

The Australian Government is aware of the establishment of the United States All-Domain Anomaly Resolution Office (AARO), and Defence monitors AARO reports. There are no plans to replicate a similar mechanism.

The Government remains committed to aviation safety and national security. Should there be a compelling reason to believe existing reporting mechanisms are insufficient, the Government would reconsider.
Thank you again for forwarding Petition EN5115 for my consideration.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Marles
Veterans
Dear Ms Templeman

span.span: PETITION EN5125—GOVERNANCE SAFEGUARD FOR SOUND MEDICAL SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE

p.span: Thank you for your correspondence of 1 August 2023 regarding Parliamentary Petition EN5125 seeking amendment to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA) in relation to governance for the Repatriation Medical Authority's (RMA) consideration of "sound medical-scientific evidence" (SMSE).

I note the petitioners' view that the VEA "…fails to provide governance ensuring all SMSE used by the RMA has been generated in a manner which reflects community qualities, standards and expectations in such areas as safety and ethics". I also understand the petition to be contending that this could be addressed by giving the Australian Commission on Safety and Quality in Health Care (ACSQHC), through the National Safety and Quality Health Service (NSQHS) Standards, a legislated role to examine all information to ensure it is in accordance with the National Clinical Trials Governance Framework.
The following information about the respective roles of the RMA and the ACSQHC may assist the Committee in its consideration of this petition.

As part of its function, the RMA assesses the quality of scientific literature. In conducting its investigations, the RMA uses articles found in medical literature databases such as PubMed, which is created by the US National Library of Medicine. The National Library of Medicine has a process to determine whether the scientific and editorial character and quality of a journal merit its inclusion in MEDLINE. MEDLINE's Scientific Quality Review is a rigorous, multi-step process in which many factors are assessed. The criteria for inclusion include conformity with ethical guidelines.

The RMA assesses the SMSE, and includes causal factors for medical conditions in the legislative instruments which it administers, known as Statements of Principles, where this is supported by the scientific studies which it has considered. As part of its responsibilities, the RMA periodically reviews the Statements of Principles to ensure that they remain consistent with the latest SMSE.

The ACSQHC's work is predominately in the field of health care safety and quality, including the development of national standards and the maintenance of accreditation schemes. The RMA is not a health care provider and does not itself undertake research to which health care standards or guidelines apply.

The proposal would require significant changes to the legislation under which the RMA operates. Creating an additional body to review the sound medical scientific evidence that the RMA had already deemed suitable to include in the overall body of evidence used for an investigation, would add additional processes and potentially increase timelines for completing a Statement of Principles investigation. This is because the RMA would have to delay its final conclusions whilst the oversight body approved the articles used for the investigation and then potentially redo the causal analysis using a smaller pool of evidence. This could work to the detriment of veterans if there was new scientific evidence that may lead to changes to the Statements of Principles, as it would delay their implementation into the legislation.

It would likely not be in the interests of the veteran community to create an additional oversight body that could exclude scientific evidence that might lead to the creation of a Statement of Principles factor linking a condition to Defence service. Therefore, there are no plans to adopt the suggestion raised in Petition EN5125.
Thank you for taking the time to write. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours faithfully,
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Keogh
Domestic and Family Violence
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5144 on -requiring financial institutions to outline potential risks associated with joint bank accounts and loans to minimise impacts of domestic abuse. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Government welcomes the public's views and appreciates the consideration that has been given to this matter. The Government treats matters of domestic abuse seriously and has taken strong action to address this important matter. On 17 October 2022, the Australian, state and territory governments released the National Plan to End Violence against Women and Children 2022-2032. The National Plan commits governments to partner and implement sustained actions to end violence against women and children in one generation, including action to address economic and financial abuse.

In the 2023-24 Budget, the Government provided $589.3 million to further support women's safety, including implementation of the National Plan. This was in addition to the $1.7 billion for women's safety announced in the 2022-23 October Budget.

To reach the National Plan's vision of ending gender-based violence in a generation, sustained and collective action is needed across society. Financial regulators and banks are addressing family and domestic violence:

In July 2023, the Australian Securities and Investments Commission provided a 'no action position' to enable large banks participating in the mandatory comprehensive credit reporting regime to not supply mandatory credit information and withhold notices to joint account holders in family violence situations.

The Australian Banking Association (ABA) has guidelines about preventing and responding to family and domestic violence, as well as general financial abuse that outlines the procedures and remedies banks should have in place to respond to indications or occurrences of these types of abuse. Banks have also introduced targeted measures to address this issue, implementing technological solutions to identify and block transactions with abusive descriptions.

The ABA is introducing a revised Banking Code of Conduct that includes an expanded definition of 'vulnerability', which recognises that a person's circumstances may require specific types of support, and that these circumstances may change over time.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely,
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Jones
World Health Organization
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 1 August 2023 in relation to Petition EN5174.

The World Health Organization (WHO) is, and remains, a Member State led organisation. Under international law, Member States such as Australia retain sovereignty regarding their public health policies. The WHO has no legal authority to force countries to accept any of its recommendations, and can only provide aid and assistance at Member States' request. The Australian law can only be changed by an act of the Parliament, not by any international treaty or other legal instrument.

The Australian Government is dedicated to strengthening national and global pandemic prevention, preparedness, and response and is committed to working with the Australian public and the international community to be better prepared for the next pandemic. As referred to in the Ministerial Petition referenced above, one of the major reforms through the WHO currently being considered is the development of a new international instrument on pandemic preparedness, prevention and response. This process will work to close gaps identified through independent reviews of the global response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

The intent of the new instrument is to strengthen the international community's efforts in preventing, preparing for, and responding to, future pandemics. The new instrument provides an opportunity to reduce the risk and impact of health threats, such as that posed by COVID-19, by strengthening global health systems and disease surveillance, while enhancing equity and future pandemic response. Australia is actively engaged in the Intergovernmental Negotiating Body (INB), which is drafting and negotiating the new instrument. For more information about the work of the INB, please visit the WHO at https://apps.who.int/gb/inb/.

Work is underway to ensure this negotiation process aligns with the Government priorities and the national interest. The Government will consult widely across government, with Australian stakeholders and the community throughout negotiations to ensure Australians and our region's interests are preserved and our priorities advanced.

Any new instrument will be subject to parliamentary scrutiny and consideration by the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties (JSCOT). As part of its process in scrutinising proposed treaties, JSCOT undertakes further consultation by inviting submissions from stakeholders and members of the public. Any changes to the Australian law to implement the new instrument would also have to be considered and passed by Parliament.

For more information about global health reform processes is available on the Department of Health and Aged Care website at www.health.gov.au/our-work/strengthening-global-health-and-international-pandemic-response.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Gender and Sexual Orientation
Dear Chair
Thank you for bringing to my attention the signed petition (EN5207) of 31 July 2023 calling for a federal prohibition on conversion practices and the establishment of federal anti-vilification laws.

As you are aware, Australia has a federal system of government and responsibilities for making laws are shared across the Commonwealth, states and territories, and local government. This includes laws regulating conversion practices.

While there are no national policies or laws aimed at preventing or prohibiting conversion practices, I note Victoria, Queensland, and the ACT have all passed legislation to ban conversion practices, and Tasmania, NSW, South Australia and Western Australia are considering legislation on this issue.

The Government believes all people are entitled to respect, dignity and the opportunity to participate in society regardless of their personal attributes, and recognises that to enjoy civil and political rights on an equal basis with others, people need to be able to do so free from discrimination.

The Sex Discrimination Act 1984 (Cth) prohibits discrimination on the grounds of gender identity, sexual orientation and intersex status in many areas of public life, including employment, education and in the provision of goods, services and facilities.

The Government has committed to introduce legislation to prohibit discrimination and vilification based on religious belief or activity. This legislation is not intended to impact state or territory laws relating to the unlawfulness or criminality of acts or practices.

In relation to the health system, individual doctors may have their own personal beliefs and values, but all are expected to uphold professional values and conduct. Doctors have a duty to make the care of patients their first concern and to practise medicine safely and effectively. They must be honest, ethical and trustworthy.

The Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency (AHPRA) works in partnership with health practitioner regulation national boards (National Boards) to regulate registered health professions under the oversight of all Australian Health Ministers. Each National Board publishes a code of conduct that applies to all registered health practitioners they regulate.

These codes are an important part of the National Boards' regulatory framework and help to keep the public safe by outlining the expectations of professional performance and conduct for registered health practitioners.

Where a health professional identifies a conscientious objection, they must ensure their objection does not prevent the patient from seeking treatment or receiving appropriate care, including referring to another health professional if this is in the patient's best interest.

All registered health professionals are expected to display a standard of performance and conduct that warrants the trust and respect of the community. This includes observing and practising the principles of ethical conduct. Where a patient or member of the public has concerns regarding individual health practitioners, they should contact AHPRA via its website at: www.ahpra.gov.au/Notifications.aspx.

The Government is working to achieve improved access to safe healthcare and support, and better physical health, mental health and wellbeing outcomes for LGBTIQA+ people. The Government recognises LGBTIQA+ people continue to experience discrimination, stigma, isolation, harassment, and violence, which leads to barriers accessing appropriate health care and poorer physical and mental health compared to the general population.

On 1 March 2023, the Government announced a pathway to better health for LGBTIQA+ communities. This includes the development of Australia's first 10 Year National Action Plan for the Health and Wellbeing of LGBTIQA+ people (Action Plan) and a $26 million investment in health and medical research focusing on LGBTIQA+ communities under the Medical Research Future Fund. The Action Plan will be informed by national consultation with LGBTIQA+ people, an Expert Advisory Group, and the lived experience of LGBTIQA+ people and their families, and community organisations. Approaches to improving mental health and wellbeing outcomes for LGBTIQA+ people will be considered in developing the Action Plan.

Primary Health Networks (PHNs) are funded to commission health services based on regional need, including at low or no cost where appropriate. People in need of extra support can contact their PHN to see if there are services that might be appropriate for their needs, including services for children. To find details of your local PHN, you can search using the map locator at: www.health.gov.au/resources/apps-and-tools/primary-health-network-phn-locator-map.

The Government recognises LGBTIQA+ Australians are disproportionately affected by mental illness and often face additional barriers in seeking the help and treatment they need. The following services are available to support the mental health and wellbeing of LGBTIQA+ people and their families:
Qlife (www.qlife.org.au) provides Australia-wide anonymous LGBTIQA+ peer support and referral by phone (1300 184 527) and webchat every day from 3pm—midnight.

headspace (www.headspace.org.au/online-and-phone-support) or on 1800 650 890 provides services for young people aged 12-25 years with, or at risk, of developing mild to moderate mental illness and are committed to embracing diversity and eliminating all forms of discrimination in the provision of health services.

Head to Health (www.headtohealth.gov.au) is the Australian Government's digital mental health gateway that aims to help people more easily access information, advice and free or low-cost phone and online mental health services and supports that most suit their needs.
Lifeline on 13 11 14 or via their chat service (www.lifeline.org.au).
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister representing the Attorney-General, Senator Gallagher
Remuneration and Entitlements
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 1 August 2023 regarding petition number EN5212, which proposes legislating overtime rates for working outside of scheduled hours.

Australia's workplace relations system has important protections for working hours, rostering, and overtime. Under the National Employment Standards in the Fair Work Act 2009,an employer cannot request or require an employee to work more than 38 hours in a week, unless the additional hours are reasonable. Reasonableness includes considering health and safety risks and the employee's personal circumstances, including family responsibilities.

Modern awards and agreements set out the maximum ordinary hours that can be worked and rules for when overtime rates apply. The independent Fair Work Commission (FWC) is responsible for setting award standards. Employers, employees, and organisations representing their industrial interests, can apply to vary an award. Further information is available on the FWC website at www.fwc.gov.au.

The Australian Government recognises the critical importance of ensuring Australian workers are appropriately remunerated and is committed to protecting Australian workers from exploitation. That is why the Government has introduced the Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Closing Loopholes) Bill 2023. If passed, this Bill would make it a criminal offence for employers to intentionally underpay their employees' wages, including overtime, as well as increasing the maximum civil penalties for underpayment-related breaches.
Thank you for writing to me about this important issue.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Mr Burke
Food Labelling
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Mark Butler MP, concerning a petition (EN5225) presented in the House of Representatives requesting to ban the use of glyphosate as a desiccant/harvest aid on crops and that foods containing glyphosate are mandated to be labelled as such. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter you have raised falls under my portfolio responsibilities as the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry.

I can understand concerns about the inappropriate use of agricultural chemicals. Protecting human health is the Australian Government's top priority. In Australia, agricultural and veterinary (agvet) chemicals, which includes pesticides such as glyphosate (the active ingredient in the herbicide product Roundup), are regulated under a cooperative scheme between the Commonwealth and state and territory governments. This ensures that controls are in place on both supply (Commonwealth responsibility) and at the point of use (state and territory responsibility) to deliver safety for the Australian public and environment.

The Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA) is the independent national regulator that assesses and registers agricultural chemicals before they can be supplied in Australia. The APVMA's assessments are evidence based and look at the entire suite of toxicology studies to determine the likely impacts on human health, animals, crops and the environment. The APVMA approves label instructions for the safe use of all registered chemical products.

As part of the registration process, the APVMA establishes maximum residue limits (MRLs) that apply to plant and animal produce destined for human consumption. An MRL is the highest residue concentration legally permitted in a food for sale and reflects the maximum level that could be present, as a result of the registered conditions of use for that chemical." The MRLs established in Australia are set well below the level that would be harmful to consumers and are based on good agricultural practice.

The APVMA assesses the food safety for the consumer by assessing trial data on all proposed use patterns, including all methods and timing of application, to quantify the potential residues from that use in food. Once the APVMA has assessed the expected residues from a proposed use, it assesses the potential dietary exposure as a proportion of the Australian Health Based Guidance Values to ensure the use pattern is safe. All residues and dietary exposure assessments are conducted in accordance with internationally accepted OECD methods.

The APVMA has assessed the residues in food resulting from approved label uses of glyphosate products, including use as a harvest aid. Glyphosate is approved as a harvest aid for a number of crops including barley, wheat, canola, various oilseeds and pulses. Depending on the use pattern, restrictions on the timing of treatment and harvest withholding periods apply. The APVMA is satisfied of the safety of registered glyphosate-containing products and will continue to permit use as a harvest aid according to label directions.

The APVMA evaluated a range of contemporary scientific information about glyphosate in 2016. The review found that, in Australia, when glyphosate is used in accordance with the label instructions it does not pose a cancer risk to humans—including to persons consuming food with glyphosate residues below the MRL—and is unlikely to have harmful effects on human beings or the environment. The report can be found at apvma.gov.au/node/13891. The APVMA continues to monitor international and scientific developments across the full suite of products within its remit.

Food Standards Australia New Zealand (FSANZ) is an independent statutory authority responsible for the development and maintenance of the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code (the Code), which sets out the legal requirements, including labelling requirements, for food produced or imported for sale in Australia and New Zealand. The Code can be accessed at foodstandards.gov.au/code/Pages/default.aspx.

The Code does not require agricultural or veterinary chemical residues to be declared on the label of food products. This is because the concentration of such residues must legally be below the MRLs, which are established safe limits. Therefore, the Australian Government does not, and does not intend to, mandate labels on foods regarding glyphosate concentrations below permitted MRLs.

The establishment of Australian-based MRLs that apply to imported food is mediated by FSANZ, through the MRL harmonisation proposal process. MRLs are listed in Standard 1.4.2 (Maximum Residue Limits) of the Code. If an MRL for an agricultural or veterinary chemical is not listed in Standard 1.4.2 of the Code, there must be no detectable residues of that chemical in the food.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Senator Watt
Financial Transactions
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5226 which requests legislation to mandate that businesses operating in Australia accept all forms of legal tender. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

A refusal to accept legal tender banknotes or coins is not unlawful. Providers of goods and services can specify what forms of payment they will accept prior to entering into a contract or transaction. If a provider specifies other means of payment prior to the contract or transaction, then there is no obligation for legal tender banknotes or coins to be accepted as payment.

Cash is an important payment method, particularly for certain groups in Australia, and plays a vital role in their inclusion in the wider economy. Cash is still widely accepted as a means of payment by merchants, used as a store of value, and provides resilience to the payments system during outages where digital forms of money cannot be used.

On 6 June 2023 the Government released its 'Strategic plan for the Australian Payments System', which outlines the Government's intentions for payment systems in Australia. The plan states the Government's commitment to maintaining adequate access to cash for all Australians.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Jones
Energy
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 11 September 2023 regarding petition EN5228 on the provision of subsidies to encourage people to use gas cooking appliances in order to take pressure off the electricity grid.

While the Australian Government has no plans to provide subsidies to encourage further take up of gas cooking appliances, the government has announced a $1.3 billion Household Energy Upgrades Fund in the 2023 24 Budget. This includes $1 billion for the Clean Energy Finance Corporation to partner with banks and other lenders to offer low-cost loans to upgrade homes with battery-ready solar PV and modem energy-efficient appliances. This will help more than 110,000 households lower their energy bills and take pressure off the electricity grid.

The Australian Government is also unlocking investment in the electricity grid through its Rewiring the Nation program. This program will deliver $20 billion of investment to modernise the grid and implement the Australian Energy Market Operator's Integrated System Plan (ISP), driving down power prices and reducing emissions by boosting renewable energy.

We are also investing to increase the capacity of the electricity grid through the Capacity Investment Scheme, which will support at least 6 GW of new dispatchable electricity generation capacity to boost reliability of electricity supply.
Thank you again for bringing this matter to the government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Coal Seam Gas Mining
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 regarding petition number EN5230, which requests a ban of all coal seam gas (CSG) operations until a safe, long-term salt storage technology can be created.

The Australian Government's role in regulating CSG projects is in relation to matters of national environmental significance protected under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act), such as listed threatened species and ecological communities, World and National Heritage places, and water resources in relation to CSG and large coal mines. The management of other environmental aspects of CSG projects is regulated by state governments.

For CSG projects approved under the EPBC Act, strict conditions have been applied which require the development and implementation of a CSG water management strategy to ensure the disposal of salt/brine waste is safely managed. Waste storage and disposal facilities, including for salt, are primarily regulated by the Queensland state government.

Regarding the specific disposal site referenced near Chinchilla, it is the responsibility of the proponent to refer their proposal for assessment under the EPBC Act if a significant impact on nationally protected matters is likely. My department has contacted the proponent and informed them of their obligation to refer the action if it is likely to have a significant impact on nationally protected matters. It remains the responsibility of the proponent to comply with the requirements of the EPBC Act.
Thank you for the opportunity to respond to this petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence regarding Petition EN5233 requesting the House to pause the use of Pfizer and Moderna Sars-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines nationwide immediately so that new data can be evaluated by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) and appropriate bodies. I apologise for the delay in responding.

I appreciate that the petitioners are very concerned about COVID-19 vaccine-related safety, however, there is no credible evidence that there is an unacceptable risk with the COVID-19 mRNA vaccines. The TGA, part of the Department of Health and Aged Care, currently implements extensive surveillance and safety monitoring to ensure the safety of the Australian population.

Although these vaccines initially received provisional approval, the TGA approved the transition of Moderna's monovalent Spikevax COVID-19 vaccine from provisional to full registration on 21 April 2023, and Pfizer's monovalent Comirnaty COVID-19 vaccine on 13 July 2023. This means that they are now fully approved for use and supply in Australia.

In making this decision, the TGA carefully considered confirmatory long term follow up data, cumulative of clinical studies and post authorisation clinical effectiveness, immunogenicity, and safety data. Further, the decision to grant full registration was informed by expert advice from the Advisory Committee on Vaccines, an independent committee with expertise in scientific, medical, and clinical fields that also has consumer representation.
