As background, all COVID-19 vaccines have been approved via the provisional approval pathway because of the urgent nature of the COVID-19 pandemic. I assure you that the TGA has comprehensively evaluated each of the provisionally registered COVID-19 vaccines to ensure that they meet Australia's high standards of safety, quality, and efficacy. These vaccines have received the same high level of scrutiny as other prescription medicines and vaccines. Although use of this pathway balances the benefits in enabling earlier access against the potential risks inherent in the fact that additional data is required, it does not release the sponsor from having to provide extensive and accurate assessment information to support the safety and efficacy of their product. As part of the provisional approval, sponsors are also required to continue to submit longer term evidence to the TGA. Data from ongoing trials can support an application to transition to full registration status if the sponsor chooses to do so.

Following approval of a vaccine, the TGA undertakes post-market surveillance. Many of these processes have been enhanced for COVID-19 vaccines making this the most intensive safety monitoring of therapeutic goods ever conducted in Australia. When investigations identify new safety information, the TGA takes prompt regulatory action. Additionally, the TGA reviews all deaths reported in people post-administration of a COVID-19 vaccine. Their analysis of individual reports and patterns of reporting does not suggest that the vaccines played a causal role in most of these cases.

Decisions relating to the vaccination program are based on the expert clinical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI), which comprises experts in infectious disease, immunisation, primary care, and public health. The ATAGI closely monitors local and international epidemiological data in relation to COVID-19 and vaccines and meet frequently to consider emerging evidence and information.

Vaccination against COVID-19 is the most effective way to reduce severe illness, hospitalisation, and death from infection. Evidence from more than 13 billion vaccine doses given worldwide shows that COVID-19 vaccines have a very good safety profile in all age groups. The protective benefits of vaccination far outweigh the potential risks.

Therefore, an immediate pause of the use of Pfizer and Moderna vaccines nationwide so that new data can be evaluated by the TGA and appropriate bodies would not be appropriate. As outlined, the TGA and ATAGI are currently conducting continuous surveillance of, and safety investigations into, the COVID-19 mRNA vaccines with evidence indicating that the benefits of the vaccine in protecting against COVID-19 disease continue to outweigh the risks.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Housing
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 11 September 2023 regarding Petition EN5241, which requests the House of Representatives support the idea of building a new city in the Mount Kosciuszko National Park (MKNP) to help solve the national housing crisis.

MKNP is not owned by the Commonwealth. It is wholly owned by the NSW Government and is administered under the NSW National Parks and Wildlife Act 1974 by the NSW Department of Planning and Environment. Therefore, the Commonwealth is not in a position to either develop or sell land in the MKNP.

The Australian Government is committed to supporting regional Australia, as laid out in our Regional Investment Framework. The Framework is delivering regional investment across four key priorities—investing in people, investing in places, investing in services and investing in industries and local economies. Through major infrastructure projects we are also increasing the capacity, reliability and connectivity of the national telecommunication, rail and road networks. These projects are creating new business and job opportunities to support the growth of regional areas—allowing more Australians to choose where live and work.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter and I trust this information will be of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms Catherine King
Parliamentarians' Entitlements
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email dated 11 September 2023 to Senator the Hon Katy Gallagher, Minister for Finance, regarding petition EN5267 requesting the cessation of resources provided to former Prime Ministers. Resources provided to former Prime Ministers are the responsibility of the Prime Minister, who has asked me to reply on his behalf.

For many years, resources have been provided to former Prime Ministers once they leave parliament to support and recognise the continued public nature of their role. Former Prime Ministers regularly participate in public engagements in an official capacity and make an ongoing contribution to the community.

These resources are specified in the Parliamentary Business Resources (former Prime Ministers) Determination 2017 and are broadly consistent between various former Prime Ministers. The costs of these resources are reported by the Independent Parliamentary Expenses Authority.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Australian Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, Mr Gorman
Feral Animal Management
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 regarding Petition EN5268 in which signatories outlined concerns about the use of toxins for the control of vertebrate pest animals, specifically feral cats and foxes.

I recently released for public consultation an updated threat abatement plan for predation from feral cats. This plan includes the appropriate and controlled use of toxins to limit harms to our unique and threatened native species.

Australia is one of the most biodiverse countries on earth. Unfortunately, Australia also holds the unenviable record of having lost more mammal species than any other continent. Feral cats and foxes are, in large part, responsible for these and many other species becoming extinct—and cats threaten more than 200 federally-listed threatened species.

Feral cats are present across 99.9 per cent of the country- they are absent only on some islands and fenced areas from which they are specifically excluded. Each year feral cats kill more than 1.5 billion native animals. Some of our rarest native species, like the Kyloring (Western ground parrot) are being kept alive only because of cat and fox baiting programs.

Signatories to the petition are concerned about the potential for non-target species to ingest toxins (either directly or by consuming carrion) and for environmental contamination. I understand these concerns but can reassure petitioners that 1080 is broken down quickly in the environment and that baiting programs are carefully tailored to the target species in order to minimise impacts on other species. More targeted than traditional baiting, the Felixer grooming trap deploys a gel squirt of toxin only when its artificial intelligence recognises a passing cat, avoiding non-target impacts.

At a population scale, there have been many scientific studies which have considered the risks of 1080 poison on native animals, including 29 species of native birds, seven species of native reptiles and amphibians and 44 species of native mammals (including carnivorous marsupials). All these studies have found that there is no threat from 1080 poison to populations of these wildlife species.
Governments will continue to ensure that control methods for feral cats and foxes are as humane, effective and targeted as possible and to look for more and better ways to save our native species.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my notice.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
Gambling
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email of 11 September 2023 on behalf of 8 signatories regarding Petition EN5272—Bring online poker back to Australia.

The Australian Government recognises the ongoing community concerns about the harms associated with online gambling. The Government is committed to guaranteeing online gambling takes place under a robust legislative framework with strong consumer protections. The current priority of the Government for online gambling is harm minimisation and to deliver consumer protection measures that are aligned with community expectations.

On 15 September 2022, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Social Policy and Legal Affairs launched an inquiry into online gambling and its impacts on those experiencing gambling harm. The Committee examined a range of issues, including the effectiveness of current gambling advertising restrictions, and regulatory and licensing regimes around online gambling.

The Committee handed down its final report on 28 June 2023 and the Government is now considering the Committee's 31 recommendations. Information about the inquiry and its final report can be found at:
.www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/House/Social_Policy_and_Legal_Affairs/Onlinegamblingimpacts.
Separately, the Government is progressing a number of important consumer protections to reduce online gambling harms, including:

BetStop, the National Self-Exclusion Register: On 21 August 2023, the Government launched BetStop, the National Self-Exclusion Register, which allows individuals experiencing gambling harms to exclude themselves from Australian licensed online wagering services for three months, up to a lifetime. The Government has also introduced mandatory customer pre-verification requirements to open a betting account. Pre-verification will ensure protection for underage or self-excluded customers from accessing online gambling services.

Banning credit betting: on 13 September 2023, I introduced in the House of Representatives the Interactive Gambling Amendment (Credit and Other Measures) Bill 2023, which would ban the use of credit cards for online wagering.

Consistent gambling messaging: new evidence-based gambling taglines were introduced on 30 March 2023 to replace 'gamble responsibly' and must accompany all gambling advertisements that appear online, as well as on TV and radio.

Classification: on 29 March 2023, the Government announced proposed improvements to the National Classification Scheme to address concerns about gambling-like content in video games. This includes a proposed mandatory minimum classification of Rl8+ for games that contain simulated gambling and M for games that contain paid loot boxes.

Continued progress towards strengthening Australia's legislative framework and ensuring harm reduction measures are in place is essential before there is any consideration of legalising a new gambling service in Australia.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Aviation Industry

Thank you for yow- email of 11 September 2023 regarding petition EN5275, presented in the House of Representatives, requesting the House pass legislation that forces airlines to compensate passengers who experience significant disruption as a result of delays or cancellations.
I thank the 31 signatories to this petition for their engagement on this important issue.

The Australian Government has committed to delivering an Aviation White Paper to set the scene for the next generation of growth and development across the aviation sector. This includes considering as a priority the economic reforms needed to improve productivity across the sector, such as addressing skills shortages and competition between airports and airlines. As a priority, the White Paper process will also consider consumer protection issues, including those proposed within this petition.

The Aviation White Paper is due to be released in mid-2024. Further information can be found at
.www.infrastructure.gov.au/infrastructure-transport-vehicles/aviation/aviation-white-paper. I encourage all interested parties to take engage in this process and have their say.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms Catherine King MP
Nuclear Energy
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 regarding petition EN5285 to change the Commonwealth prohibition on civil nuclear power. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.
The Australian Government has no plans to change the longstanding moratorium on nuclear power in Australia. which is prohibited by the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.

The GenCost 2022-23 Report, prepared by the CSIRO and the Australian Energy Market Operator (AEMO), shows renewables are the cheapest form of generation for Australia, even when additional costs for storage and new transmission are included. Renewable technologies are quicker to build and cheaper to operate, making nuclear power an unviable choice for Australia.

Putting downwards pressure on electricity prices is why we are focused on transforming our electricity system so that more renewable energy powers our homes. Under the government's Powering Australia plan, we are investing $20 billion through Rewiring the Nation to upgrade our electricity grid to ensure it can support the boost needed in renewable energy generation. We are also supporting 6 GW of dispatchable renewable capacity investment through the Capacity Investment Scheme, investing $100 million in solar banks and $200 million in new community batteries to help more people access solar and maximise the benefits of Australia's energy transformation.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Asylum Seekers
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 enclosing Petition EN5289 with 14 signatures, concerning Mr Zafar Aziz's request for Ministerial Intervention.

As you may be aware, Home Affairs Portfolio Ministers have personal intervention powers under the Migration Act 1958 that allow them to grant a visa to a person or to lift an application bar to allow a visa application, if they think it is in the public interest to do so. The public interest powers are non- compellable, that is, the Ministers are not required to exercise their power. What is in the public interest is a matter for the Ministers to define.

Requests for Ministerial Intervention are assessed on a case-by-case basis and processing timeframes vary due to individual circumstances. All information provided with a Ministerial Intervention request is taken into account when considering a case.
Please be assured that the Petition has been noted and will be considered when a decision is made on Mr Aziz's request.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5289 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Electric Vehicles
Dear Chair

Thank you for referring a copy of petition EN5297 presented to the House of Representatives on 11 September 2023 regarding imposing a responsibility on public electric vehicle (EV) charger owners to ensure operational chargers. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

I understand the reasoning of petitioners and I am sympathetic to the matters they raise. However, the Government is not considering introducing retrospective fines for EV charger operators. Instead, the Government is committed to working with all levels of government and industry to build a customer-focused EV charging ecosystem in Australia that is convenient, reliable and equitable. The needs of Australian motorists are a central consideration for Government in designing future policy to support the decarbonisation of Australia's transport sector, including policies to support EV charging infrastructure and overcome range anxiety.

As part of our Powering Australia plan to improve affordability, create jobs and reduce emissions, the Australian Government has developed Australia's first National Electric Vehicle Strategy. The Strategy provides a nationally consistent, comprehensive framework to consider supply, demand, and infrastructure needs for cleaner and cheaper vehicles in Australia.

The Strategy builds on the progress made across Australia in supporting EV uptake. It includes an agreement to work across jurisdictions on six key areas of collaboration—including national standards; and remote and regional EV charging infrastructure. As part of this work, we are collaborating to establish minimum operating standards for government-funded public EV charging infrastructure. Availability and accessibility are some of the key factors being considered as part of these standards to ensure EV drivers can travel with confidence.

In addition to collaborating across jurisdictions, the Government is investing $39.3 million through the Driving the Nation Fund, matched by the NRMA to deliver 117 new public fast chargers on national highways. Priority will be given to known EV charging blackspots, particularly in rural and remote areas. Specifications include reliability targets to ensure this network is accessible and well maintained.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Coal Seam Gas Mining
Dear Chair,

Thank you for your email of 12 September 2023, presenting petition number EN5299, asking the Federal and State Governments of Australia to ban hydraulic fracturing. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Australian Government is committed to delivering Australia's energy transformation alongside strong climate action. Gas will continue to be a key fuel as we transform our energy system, providing the flexibility we need to add more renewables to the grid. Gas is essential for energy security, stability, and reliability both domestically and across the Asia-Pacific. Australian gas, exported as liquefied natural gas, is critical to our trading partners' own net zero plans.

The Government is strongly committed to protecting our environment and enforcing safe and environmentally sustainable practices by the oil and gas sector, now and into the future. Onshore gas developments are subject to rigorous environmental approvals processes across state, territory, and commonwealth regulatory bodies. As Australia's states and territories regulate onshore gas development, changes to these regulatory settings is a matter for the relevant jurisdiction. Offshore gas developments are regulated by Australia's independent expert regulator, the National Offshore Petroleum Safety and Environmental Management Authority.

However, where a gas development could impact a matter of national environmental significance, it is assessed under our national environment law, the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). On 8 December 2022, the Government released its Response to the Independent Review of the EPBC Act. In this response, we indicated our intention to strengthen environmental protections in relation to hydraulic fracturing by expanding the coverage of the EPBC's water trigger to all forms of unconventional gas extraction. The response can be reviewed here:
.dcceew.gov.au/environment/epbc/publications/nature-positive-plan.

Over the past decade successive Australian governments have supported a number of scientific studies examining the potential impacts of gas development on water resources and the environment. Independent scientific assessments by the CSIRO and Geoscience Australia into hydraulic fracturing have found with high confidence that potential impacts can be mitigated through ongoing compliance with existing regulatory and management controls. The findings can be viewed at www.bioregionalassessments.gov.au/gba.

The role of gas is changing as Australia and the rest of the world decarbonises. I am leading the development of a Future Gas Strategy to help us plan for and support Australia, and our region's, transition to net zero. To develop the Strategy, I welcome feedback from anyone with an interest in the future of gas. I encourage the petitioners to contribute to the development of the Future Gas Strategy. Information on how to contribute can be found at www.industry.gov.au/mining-oil-and-gas/oil-and-gas/planning-gas-2050.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Resources, Ms Madeleine King
Housing
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email dated 11 September 2023 to the Minister for Social Services, the Hon Amanda Rishworth MP, concerning a petition to change Commonwealth Rent Assistance (CRA). The Minister has asked me to respond to you on her behalf.

The Albanese Labor Government understands the importance of safe and affordable housing for all Australians. In 2023-24, this Government expects to spend around $5.5 billion in CRA to assist households receiving income support to pay their rent and around $1.7 billion through the National Housing and Homelessness Agreement to assist states and territories to deliver social housing and homelessness services.

CRA is an important component of the income support and family payment systems. It contributes to the improvement of housing affordability and complements broader income support objectives by assisting individuals and families with the additional costs associated with renting in the private market and in community housing. CRA is not intended to reimburse recipients for the full cost of their private rent.

Security of tenure is one of the significant benefits of owning a home, which is why CRA is not extended to home owners. There are other concessions in the social security system for home owners. For example, the value of a person's principal home is not taken into account in working out the amount of pension or benefit they can receive. If the value of a person's home was treated in the same way as other assets, such as bank accounts or shares, many home owners will receive far less in pensions or benefits than is currently the case.

Home owner pensioners can still receive a range of concessions, including subsidised prescription medicines under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, and subsidised health care and related products. State and territory governments and some private providers also offer Pensioner Concession Card holders discounts on other goods and services, such as utility bills and public transport.

The Albanese Labor Government has committed to an ambitious housing reform agenda which will boost the supply of all housing—more public and social housing, more affordable housing, more homes to rent and more homes to buy. This includes:
a $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund to support 30,000 new social and affordable rental homes over its first 5 years;
$2 billion through the Social Housing Accelerator to deliver thousands of social homes across Australia;
a National Housing Accord with states and territories, local government and industry, with a shared ambition to build one million new well-located homes over 5 years from 2024;
a $3 billion New Home Bonus, to incentivise states and territories to build more homes;
a $500 million Housing Support Program, a competitive funding program for local and state governments;
increasing the National Housing Finance and Investment Corporation's liability cap by $2 billion to provide lower cost and longer-term finance to community housing providers;
working with states and territories to deliver the Help to Buy Scheme, supporting up to 40,000 low and middle-income families to purchase a home of their own;
an additional $1 billion to be invested in the National Housing Infrastructure Facility (NHIF) to support more new homes;
investing $1.7 billion in 2023-24 in payments to state governments as part of the one-year extension of the National Housing and Homelessness Agreement; and
developing a National Housing and Homelessness Plan to identify the short, medium and long-term steps needed to address housing issues in Australia.
The Minister appreciates the Standing Committee on Petitions bringing this matter to her attention, and the opportunity to provide a reply to this petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Social Services, Ms Elliot (Petition No. EN5300)
Human Rights: Pakistan
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your letter containing petition EN5316 regarding the security situation and its negative impacts on the population in Kurram district in Pakistan.

The Australian Government acknowledges the significant security challenges faced by Pakistan, including in Kurram and surrounding districts in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province. These areas have been host to long-running insurgency groups hostile to Pakistan. Most of Kybher Pakhtunkhwa and neighbouring Balochistan province are listed as 'Do not travel' destinations in the Australian Government's travel advice due to the volatile security situation and ongoing threat of terrorist attacks, kidnapping and violence.

Australia has longstanding defence, law enforcement and institutional ties with Pakistan, and engages with Pakistani counterparts on security matters. We condemn terrorism and continue to stand with Pakistan in its fight against regional and global terror groups.

Australia also urges relevant authorities to improve governance and development outcomes in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa. Over the past decade Australia has made a significant contribution towards development in the province, including the former Federally Administered Tribal Areas (FATA), through development cooperation in the areas of education, governance and service delivery, and women's empowerment.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Universities
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 September 2023 regarding Petition EN5321—Pay research students a living wage.

Research plays a critical role in Australia, driving innovation and improving our quality of life. The Australian Government acknowledges the invaluable work higher degree by research (HDR) students undertake to support and advance Australia's research and knowledge base, and welcomes their views and opinions.

The Government's Research Training Program (RTP) stipend is a scholarship awarded by universities for the purposes of students' education. It is specifically designed to support HDR students and is not considered as income for employment or employment related activities. It is therefore not linked to any benchmarks such as the National Minimum Wage.

Under the Commonwealth Scholarships Guidelines (Research) 2017 (Guidelines), universities have discretion to award RTP stipend rates within a base and maximum range. In 2023, the full-time base RTP stipend rate is $29,863 and the maximum rate is $46,653. In 2024, the full-time base RTP stipend rate will be $32,192, and the maximum rate will be $50,291. The range acknowledges that universities are best placed to determine the stipend rates that will enable them to achieve their research training priorities and meet the needs of their HDR students. The stipend rates offered by universities varies, and many exercise their discretion to raise their rates above the full-time base rate.

The Guidelines also stipulate that RTP stipend recipients are entitled to various types of leave. This includes paid recreation and sick leave for each year of RTP stipend support. Recipients who have completed at least 12 months of their HDR while in receipt of an RTP stipend are also entitled to paid maternity leave or a period of paid parenting leave (subject to the usual practices of the university).

The Australian Universities Accord (the Accord) process is reviewing Australia's higher education system and is considering a range of issues for research and research training policy settings, including those that attract and support HDR students. The Accord Panel has provided its Interim Report, with a final report due to be delivered to Government by December 2023. Further information about the Accord, including the Interim Report, is available on the Department of Education's website at www.education.gov.au/australian-universities-accord.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare
Live Sheep Exports
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 5 September 2023 concerning Petition EN5323, seeking a legislated end date for the phase out of live sheep exports by sea. The Australian Government acknowledges the considerable community concerns about animal welfare in the trade of live sheep exports by sea and understands the desire to see action.

The government took the commitment to phase out live sheep exports by sea to two elections, and it is my intention to deliver on this commitment in an orderly and considered way, and in consultation with affected stakeholders. The phase out will not take place during this term of the Australian Parliament to give time for individuals and businesses to prepare for a transition away from live sheep exports by sea.

Earlier this year I appointed a four-person, Independent Panel to provide advice on timing and the mechanism for implementing the phase out of live sheep exports by sea. The Independent Panel has undertaken an extensive consultation process and is now considering the information it received. The panel has heard the views of a broad range of stakeholders, including producers, supply chain participants, exporting businesses, community groups, animal welfare organisations and trading partners. I look forward to receiving the panel's report by 25 October 2023 and considering its recommendations.

Consideration of the panel's recommendations will also give me and the government guidance for a timeframe for the phase out of live sheep exports by sea, including any necessary legislative processes.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Senator Watt
Nuclear Energy
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 regarding petition EN5335 on the development of nuclear fusion reactors. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Australian Government has committed to reduce emissions to 43 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030 and to net zero by 2050. Nuclear fusion remains an experimental technology and will be developed and commercialised too slowly to help Australia meet these targets. The International Atomic Energy Agency, for example, reports that the building and operation of demonstration, electricity-producing fusion power plants could occur by 2050, depending on funding and technical advancement.

The GenCost 2022-23 Report, prepared by the CSIRO and the Australian Energy Market Operator, shows that renewables are the cheapest form of generation for Australia, even when additional costs for storage and new transmission are included. Renewable technologies are quicker to build and cheaper to operate than nuclear power facilities.

The legislative prohibition on the approval of nuclear power plants under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 does not differentiate between nuclear technologies. The government has no plans to change the longstanding moratorium on nuclear power in Australia, or the laws which prohibit its deployment.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of this petition to the government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 enclosing Petition EN5341, with 1785 signatures, concerning processing times for a Permanent Residence (Skilled Regional) (subclass 191) visa in the Regional Provisional stream

The Australian Government recognises the important and valuable contribution that regional visa holders have made in closing labour and skills gaps and supporting businesses and communities through their commitment to living, working and studying in regional areas of Australia while on a pathway to permanent residence.

Processing of applications for regional visas, such as the subclass 191 visa and applications relating to occupations in regional Australia have priority, as per Ministerial Direction 100, in order to support regional workforce needs. In this program year (beginning 1 July 2023) there have been more than 1,400 subclass 191 visas granted in the Regional Provisional stream. More information is available at: http://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-processing- times/skilled-visa-processing-priorities.

Recently, the Government announced further funding in the 2023-24 Budget for visa processing officers, with an additional $48.1 million over 12 months to continue efforts to manage the number of visas on-hand. This follows the Government's announcement investment of $36 million in September 2022 at the Jobs and Skills Summit about the onboarding of an extra 500 positions to support visa processing. As a result, the Department of Home Affairs is making significant inroads in reducing on hand visa backlog and finalising applications. Actual processing time can vary due to individual circumstances including whether a complete application has been made and the time to perform required checks and receive more information about health, character, and national security requirements.

You may be interested to know that in June 2023 the Department clarified that there is no minimum income requirement for eligible applicants for a subclass 191 visa. Applicants must, however, provide notices of assessment issued by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) for three income years out of the five years of their eligible provisional visa. Further information is available at http://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/skilled-regional-191.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5341 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Health Care
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 regarding petition EN5343 on the Australian Government's decision to increase maximum dispensing quantities for some medications listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).

The Government's decision to implement this measure was based on the recommendation of the independent expert Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee and has patient benefit and reducing cost-of-living pressures at its core.

Increasing medicines quantities provided on a single script will deliver significant savings for patients, which is why it is an accepted practice in many comparable countries around the world. Patients in countries that Australia most commonly compares itself to have similar arrangements in place, where patients can access up to 90 or 100 days of commonly used medicines on a single script.

The Government is committed to supporting better access to healthcare for all Australians, including through critical services provided by pharmacists. The Government is committed to a vibrant community pharmacy sector in Australia, with a growing role for pharmacy in primary healthcare. Investment in expanded pharmacy programs is key in ensuring patients have greater and easier access to critical health services through their local community pharmacy.

Every single dollar that will be saved by the Government from lower dispensing fees paid to pharmacies, will be reinvested straight back into community pharmacy, funding pharmacy services that directly benefit patients. This will be achieved through:

$654.9 million over four years for Community Pharmacy Programs. This includes increasing the total budget for Programs under the Seventh Community Pharmacy Agreement (7CPA) from $1.2 billion to $1.4 billion, as well as securing funding for these programs to continue beyond the 7CPA.

$377.3 million over four years for a nationally consistent, Commonwealth funded Opioid Dependent Treatment Program, which commenced 1 July 2023. This is in addition to dispensing related remuneration for these medicines under the Section 100 Highly Specialised Drugs Community Access Program. Pharmacies are expected to receive $175 to $191 per patient, per month under these new arrangements.

$114.1 million over four years to expand the vaccines administered by a pharmacist under the National Immunisation Program. From 1 January 2024, pharmacists will be paid $18.85 per vaccine administered—the same rate a GP receives for a Level A consultation to provide the same service. This is something multiple pharmacy stakeholders have asked successive Governments for. Which vaccines a pharmacist can administer varies between states/territories depending on local legislation.

$79.5 million over four years to double the total annual budget for the Regional Pharmacy Maintenance Allowance, ensuring regional, rural and remote Australians have continued access to their local pharmacy.

$148.2 million over four years for the Regional Pharmacy Transition Allowance. This allowance will provide additional Government assistance to pharmacies in regional, rural, and remote Australia. The RPTA will temporarily support eligible pharmacies in Modified Monash (MM) Model MM2-7 with funding support phasing down across four years as pharmacy owners transition business arrangements to account for 60-day dispensing.

These measures will ensure the ongoing strength of this part of the health sector and provide new opportunities for expanded pharmacist scope of practice. It benefits people accessing their medicines, it benefits pharmacists in managing their workload and delivering more advanced clinical services and it benefits GPs and other prescribers serving their community. These measures will ensure the pharmacists who work in community pharmacy will be able to get out from behind the counter and provide more tailored support to Australians. We will continue to support hard working pharmacists, while ensuring Australians can manage cost of living pressures.

At a time of immense change in the Australian healthcare system, the Australian Government has already commenced negotiations around the Eighth Community Pharmacy Agreement {8CPA). Should consultation proceed well, it is the intention of the Australian Government to seek to finalise negotiations for an 8CPA and have it commence by 1 March 2024. The Government is committed to developing a new agreement in partnership, and through negotiation, with the pharmacy sector. Consultations for the 8CPA will include patient groups, medicines wholesalers and distributors, and others who have a stake in the growth and development of pharmacy services that benefit all Australians.

The Government is committed to supporting a thriving community pharmacy sector. The implementation of 60-day dispensing is occurring over three phases in 12 months to minimise the disruption to pharmacies and allow them to adjust. We will continue to support hard working pharmacists through the reinvestments and additional funding, whilst ensuring Australians can manage cost. of living pressures.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Myanmar
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding a petition presented in the House of Representatives on the subject of the Myanmar military regime.

The Australian Government remains deeply concerned about the deteriorating situation in Myanmar, and the ongoing repression and violence of the military regime. Since the military staged a coup in February 2021, the people of Myanmar have demonstrated their courage and commitment to a democratic country, and have shown determined resilience in the face of unspeakable atrocities. We continue to stand with the people of Myanmar in the face of increasing repression and violence by the military regime.

The Australian Government uses all levers at our disposal, bilaterally, regionally, and multilaterally, to press for the cessation of violence, safe and unhindered humanitarian access, the release of all those unjustly detained, and full implementation of ASEAN's Five-Point Consensus.

On 1 February 2023, I announced additional autonomous sanctions on those directly responsible for the military coup and ongoing repression and violence in Myanmar. This includes targeted financial sanctions and travel bans on 16 individuals responsible for the coup and the violence and oppression of the subsequent military regime, and targeted financial sanctions on two military-controlled entities. These announcements built upon existing targeted financial sanctions and travel bans against five members of the Myanmar military. Australia has maintained a long-standing arms embargo on Myanmar, and we support calls for a global arms embargo.

Australia will continue to monitor the regime's actions, and we will keep our targeted sanctions towards Myanmar under review. Consistent with the approach we take on all sanctions regimes, it would not be appropriate to discuss whether specific persons or entities might be under consideration. Sanctions are just one foreign policy tool at our disposal, and we will continue to calibrate our response to the Myanmar crisis, taking into consideration a range of factors.

Australia will continue to support the people of Myanmar through the provision of development and humanitarian assistance, including $121 million in 2023-24. We prioritise the needs of the most poor and vulnerable, with an emphasis on women and girls, and vulnerable groups in hard to reach and conflict-affected areas.

Australia is committed to maintaining global attention on the crisis in Myanmar, and we will continue to work closely with regional and international partners to find options to de- escalate the crisis and support efforts towards a resolution.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong (Petition No. EN5344)
Water
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 regarding petition EN5345 on the implementation of water-friendly policies, which was recently presented in the House.

The petition highlights the importance of securing Australia's water future—something I am very passionate about. Our nation faces considerable pressure on managing our water resources sustainably due to climate change and increasing demands from a growing population.
The Australian Government has developed and implemented several water-friendly policies to assist with achieving water security for our nation.

The Government is investing responsibly in water infrastructure projects that support water security in regional and remote communities through the National Water Grid Fund. This includes projects that improve water reliability and quality to meet Australian Drinking Water Guidelines, particularly in remote First Nations communities. Additionally, the fund invests in water efficiency and recycling projects to increase resilience to climate change by supplementing water supplies, particularly for agriculture, industrial use, and community green spaces. An example of this is the Government's investment in projects involving reuse of treated wastewater in industrial and agricultural production. Further information on the National Water Grid Fund and existing projects is at nationalwatergrid.gov.au.

The Water Efficiency Labelling and Standards (WELS) scheme was established in 2005. It is a cooperative initiative between the Commonwealth, state and territory governments and industry. The scheme reduces demand for potable water by informing consumers about the water efficiency of household products, including taps, showers, toilets, urinals, washing machines and dishwashers at the point of sale. WELS helps businesses and consumers to make decisions that can reduce their water use, saving them money on water and energy bills while improving national water security and reliability across Australia.
WELS has been successful in contributing to estimated savings of:
1,321 gigalitres of water through reduced water and energy bills estimated at more than $11 billion dollars;
165 gigalitres of water in 2023, which is likely to be 230 gigalitres per year by 2036;
$1.5 billion in water and water-heating utility bills this year, which is likely to be savings of $2.6 billion a year by 2036; and
24.2 metric tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent (Mt CO2 -e) in 2023.

The National Water Initiative, a shared commitment signed by all Australian governments in 2004, has also played a key role in guiding sustainable water policy and reform for nearly 20 years. Significant progress has been made in implementing actions under the agreement. It has promoted more efficient water use, particularly in urban settings, and encouraged the uptake of innovative water supplies such as recycled water. I am building on this by developing a new National Water Initiative to guide water reform and sustainable water use under climate change. We will explore ways to ensure we use our limited water resources wisely, including water efficiency and the use of all water supply methods.

A key part of securing Australia's water future is ensuring water security for the environment. This is why the Government is committed to implementing the Murray-Darling Basin Plan in full. I introduced the Water Amendment Bill to Parliament on 6 September 2023 to support this. If passed, the amendments I proposed will give us more time and more options to deliver the 450 gigalitres of water for the environment. This is essential to protect our river ecosystems from environmental collapse, and to save our native animals from extinction.
These are just some examples of the work the Government is doing on behalf of all Australians to achieve water security for our nation.

The Government is looking ahead to determine what a water secure future looks like and how we can help Australia get there. As I have been listening to stakeholders, I have continued to affirm that all options are on the table. We welcome ideas for managing Australia's water resources sustainably.
Thank you for writing to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
Eczema
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 regarding petition EN5346 on support for the formation of a National Eczema Strategy.

The Australian Government acknowledges that eczema sufferers and health professionals are currently calling for the development of a national strategy for eczema to improve the care and management of Australians impacted by this condition. I am aware that Eczema Support Australia (ESA) is recommending that a national eczema strategy contain the following two main priority actions: eczema management education and support for patients and their families; and eczema education and management support for primary care health professionals and junior doctors.

I understand that the Australasian College of Dermatology and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners are also supporting the call for a national eczema strategy which is advocating for measures to address the national dermatology workforce shortage and lack of training for GPs, and the establishment of an eczema registry.

I understand ESA has recently released a White Paper 'The Burden of Eczema—Evidence for a National Strategy' which provides an evaluation of the financial and humanistic burden of eczema in Australia in 2023. I note that this report also identifies current challenges in eczema care and makes a call to action for addressing the challenges of highest priority.

The National Strategic Framework for Chronic Conditions (Framework), endorsed by the Council of Australian Governments in 2017, is the overarching policy for the prevention and management of chronic conditions in Australia. The Framework moves away from a disease-specific approach and better considers the shared health determinants, risk factors and multi-morbidities across a broad range of chronic conditions.

As part of the 2023-24 Budget, the Government provided authority for a refresh of the Framework to be undertaken to guide sustainable and evidence-based support for chronic conditions in the future. The refresh will ensure alignment of the Framework with other strategies and action plans developed since the Framework was published, such as the National Preventive Health Strategy, as well as new evidence and international policies.

Please note that relevant staff from the Department of Health and Aged Care met with ESA on 24 July 2023 and advised ESA that, in the context of the Government moving away from a disease-specific approach to addressing chronic conditions, further condition-specific action plans are not a priority.

Regarding eczema, the Government is currently providing $16.6 million to support the National Allergy Council Jointly established by Allergy & Anaphylaxis Australia and the Australasian Society of Clinical Immunology and Allergy) to .fund activities associated with the prevention, treatment, and management of allergies. This includes the implementation of a shared care model for allergy care and provision of support for allergy sufferers, (especially for those in regional, rural, and remote areas) by upskilling health professionals through expanded training resources and new models of training delivery. The shared care model will look into establishing agreed minimum standards of care for several allergic diseases including eczema.

More broadly, in relation to addressing allergic disease and anaphylaxis in Australia, the Government as part of the 2022-23 Federal Budget, announced $10.2 million over four years to the Murdoch Children's Research Institute to expand the Centre for Food and Allergy Research to establish a National Centre of Excellence. This will centralise research on food, drug, vaccine, insect, and pollen allergies and provide accelerated access to the clinical trials of emerging allergy treatments for different types of allergies.
The Government is committed to reducing the impact of chronic conditions on the Australian population and optimising quality-of-life for impacted individuals, their families and carers.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 enclosing Petition EN5347, with 383 signatures, concerning the purchase of residential property for the Skilled Work Regional (Provisional) (subclass 491) visa holders. The Australian Government values the important role skilled regional provisional visa holders play in supporting regional economies, employers and communities.

Holders of subclass 491 visas are able to apply for the Permanent Residence (Skilled Regional) (subclass 191) visa in the Regional Provisional stream after three years, provided they meet the eligibility criteria for that visa—including having complied with the conditions of their skilled regional visa. Once granted, this visa would provide access to government payments, services and benefits available to Australian permanent residents, subject to any waiting periods that may apply.

On 27 April 2023, the Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, the Hon Clare O'Neil MP, released 'A Migration System for a More Prosperous and Secure Australia—Outline of the Government's Migration Strategy' (the Outline), which is informed by the Migration Review.

The Government is considering how to best support regional areas and is reviewing policy settings of regional visa programs to ensure they are fit for purpose. The Outline notes the importance of working with State and Territory governments to plan our migration intake by:
Aligning investments in infrastructure, services and housing, with joint action across governments to address barriers to increasing housing supply; and
Establishing a greater role for States and Territories in identifying their migration needs and priorities, especially in regional Australia.
The Government is currently finalising the Migration Strategy and intends to release it in late 2023.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5347 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Road Safety
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 16 October 2023 regarding petition number EN5398, which relates to the regulation of Event Data Recorders (EDRs) in vehicles.

Road Safety is everybody's business and the Australian Government supports the introduction of new technologies that improve the safety of new vehicles. The Government's policy is to harmonise the national vehicle standards with international regulations wherever possible, primarily United Nations vehicle regulations. This gives Australians access to safer vehicles at the lowest cost.

There are now two international standards setting technical requirements for EDRs, one for light vehicles which entered into force in September 2021 and one for heavy vehicles has recently been agreed by the United Nations.

I am pleased to advise that my department has commenced work on developing an Australian vehicle standard for EDRs based on those international standards, and recently held a series of workshops with relevant stakeholders to progress this important work.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms Catherine King
COVID-19: Response
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 regarding petition EN5416 on behalf of 66 signatories regarding the latest COVID-19 subvariant.

On 20 October 2023, Australia's Chief Medical Officer declared that COVID-19 is no longer a Communicable Disease Incident of National Significance. This declaration was supported by the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

This declaration is in line with the announcement by the World Health Organization Director-General that the International Health Regulations 2005 Emergency Committee for COVID-19 determined that COVID-19 no longer constitutes a public health emergency of international concern.

Epidemiological data also supports this position. COVID-19 remains a serious infectious disease but no longer constitutes a public health emergency. Future waves of transmission continue to be expected across the next few years, whether due to waning immunity or new variants, but at this stage current and emerging variants are no more dangerous than other Omicron strains.

Continued uptake of protective behaviours such as vaccination and other mitigation strategies are now more appropriate than an emergency response. The primary aim of COVID-19 vaccination continues to be to reduce the risk of serious illness and death. Current vaccines are very effective in preventing serious disease (including death) in most people, but COVID-19 still poses a significant health threat to older Australians and people with multiple co-morbidities. The latest advice on COVID-19 vaccinations and boosters can be found on the Australian Technical Advisory Group on lmmunisation's website at www.health.gov.au/atagi.

With the wide availability and uptake of vaccination and oral treatments for COVID-19, the risks for the Australian population have reduced and public health measures taken by the Commonwealth, state and territory governments have changed accordingly. Australia has shifted to managing COVID-19 consistent with other common communicable diseases, focusing on prevention, reducing transmission and management of serious illness, hospitalisations and death.
For further information about the end of the COVID-19 emergency response, see www.health.gov.au/news/ahppc-statement-end-of-covid-19-emergency-response.

The Australian Government continues to balance public health and social measures against the health risks of COVID-19 to ensure our response remains proportionate, whilst protecting those most at risk.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Termination of Pregnancy
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email of 16 October 2023 to the Minister for Social Services, the Hon Amanda Rishworth MP, referring petition EN5430 relating to financial abortions. The Minister has asked me to respond to you on her behalf.
The petitioner may be interested in the following information.

The Australian Government acknowledges the petition is seeking to promote gender equality by balancing a woman's right to abortion, with the introduction of the right for men to opt out of parenthood through a financial abortion.

The Child Support Scheme is in place to ensure that, as far as possible, children remain financially secure until they reach 18 years of age. Parents have a legal responsibility to support their children until they turn 18 years of age, according to their financial capacity, regardless of whether or not they supported the pregnancy.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Social Services, Ms Elliot

subdebateinfo.title: Child Safety: Bullying, Harassment and Violence

p.span: Child Safety: Bullying, Harassment and Violence
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 on behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions concerning petition EN5433 on bullying.

I acknowledge the community concern around bullying in schools and its impact on students and their families, and mental health and wellbeing. The Australian Government takes the safety and protection of children and young people seriously. All students have the right to be safe at school and bullying of any nature is unacceptable. All schools have a responsibility to ensure that their students are safe, respected and supported each day.

While the Australian Government plays a national leadership role in setting and advocating for national priorities in school education, state and territory governments and non- government education authorities are responsible for the operations of schools. The Government values the work that state and territory government and non-government education authorities do to manage bullying in schools and ensure that appropriate measures are in place so that all students in schools can learn in safe and supportive environments. This includes the development of policies for addressing bullying.
The Government has made a range of information and resources available to support school communities to prevent and address bullying, and promote wellbeing and resilience, which are outlined below.

The Student Wellbeing Hub (the Hub) provides a range of freely available information and resources for educators, students and parents to assist them to create and maintain a safe and supportive school environment. The Hub includes free resources and professional learning opportunities for teachers, a dedicated area for parents and a collection of age- appropriate activities and resources for students from Foundation to Year 12. This includes resources to help prevent and address bullying, and to support and strengthen the integral relationship between students' social and emotional development and their learning outcomes.

The Government acknowledges that cyberbullying is a modern and evolving pressure on students, teachers and parents. To support the community to respond to this issue, the Government appointed an eSafety Commissioner. The eSafety Commissioner's website at www.esafety.qov.au provides information about cyberbullying and fact sheets on how people can assist themselves and others who may be cyberbullied. The eSafety Commissioner also investigates complaints about cyberbullying and can assist in having content removed from social media sites.

The Government has provided funding for the Bullying. No Way! website, available at www.bullyingnoway.gov.au, and associated resources for parents and teachers, and activities to support the annual National Day of Action against Bullying and Violence. The National Day of Action provides an opportunity for students and school communities to pledge their commitment to addressing bullying and violence. It is a positive day of action, empowering students and uniting school communities to find workable solutions to address bullying and violence. More than 6,400 schools registered to participate in the 2023 National Day of Action.

The Government has committed $203.7 million for the Student Wellbeing Boost to support schools to respond to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and successive lockdowns on the mental health and wellbeing of students. This initiative is comprised of 2 parts:
$192 million in additional one-off funding to schools to support their students' mental health and wellbeing.
$10.75 million for the development of Voluntary Mental Health Check Tool to enable schools to undertake a point-in-time assessment of their students' mental health and wellbeing.

The Government funds several key initiatives that provide direct and indirect support services to children and young people experiencing bullying, and the often-related impacts on their mental health and wellbeing.
In terms of direct offerings:
ReachOut provides an online mental health service for young people and their parents, which offers free information and practical tools specific to bullying.
Kids Helpline is a free, confidential online and phone counselling service available to young people 24 hours a day.

headspace offers a range of services to young people experiencing, or at risk of, mild to moderate mental illness which includes providing multidisciplinary supports and in school mental health education sessions to students and carers.

Raise Foundation delivers best practice early intervention and prevention mentoring programs to students in years 7 to 9 at public secondary schools across Australia, prioritising those most at risk of school disengagement and poor mental health and wellbeing due to a range of factors, including exposure to bullying.
Through the National Support for Child and Youth Mental Health Program, indirect support is provided to students via 2 key initiatives that boost the mental health literacy of the workforce:

The Mental Health in Education Initiative, Be You provides Australian educators in learning communities with free online training, resources, and guidance to support students with facing life's challenges, building resilience and managing their own mental health and wellbeing. Specific tools are available to help educators identify and understand bullying in the school space and assist impacted students.

The National Workforce Centre, delivered by Emerging Minds, assists educators, professionals and organisations who work with children and families, as well as parents/families themselves, to have the skills to identify, assess and support children at risk of mental health conditions through evidence-based online professional learning, information and supports. These also include targeted resources to enable professionals and families to support and respond to children who have experienced or are engaging in bullying.
I thank you for your efforts in bringing forward this petition and referring to me.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare
Housing
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email dated 16 October 2023, presenting a petition requesting the introduction of a government-regulated organisation to maintain minimum rental standards across Australia.

In relation to the petition's request, state and territory governments, under the Constitution, are responsible for the regulation of residential tenancies, including rental conditions and agreements. Each state and territory has its own tenants' advisory services, providing free and confidential advice about housing rights and possible supports. A list of tenants' unions is available at www.tenants.org.au/nato.

At National Cabinet in August this year the Commonwealth, state and territory governments committed to A Better Deal for Renters to harmonise and strengthen renters' rights across Australia. This included developing a nationally consistent framework including a requirement for genuine reasonable grounds for eviction, moving towards limiting rental increases to once a year and phasing in minimum rental standards.
These changes will make a tangible impact for the almost one-third of Australian households who rent.

The Albanese Government has committed to an ambitious housing reform agenda which will boost the supply of all housing—more public and social housing, more affordable housing, more homes to rent and more homes to buy.

These housing challenges didn't happen overnight and cannot be solved by one government alone. As mentioned, the Albanese Government is working with the states and territories and local governments to deliver better housing outcomes.
This includes the work being delivered through National Cabinet to provide more secure and affordable housing supply. Significant measures include:

The National Housing Accord that will support planning and zoning reforms, as well as investing $350 million in additional federal funding to deliver 10,000 affordable rental homes over five years from 2024—matched by the state and territories.
Federal funding of $2 billion through the Social Housing Accelerator to deliver thousands of social homes across Australia.

Federal funding of $3 billion through the New Homes Bonus to help incentivise states and territories to build more homes where people need them to meet a new national target of 1.2 million new homes over five years.

A $500 million Housing Support Program for initiatives to help kick start housing supply including connecting essential services, amenities to support new housing development or building planning capability.
A National Planning Reform Blueprint with planning, zoning, land release and other measures to improve housing supply and affordability.
These measures are in addition to the work we've already started.

The $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund (HAFF) has now started and will support 30,000 new social and affordable rental homes over its first five years. The Albanese Government has delivered on its commitment to establish the HAFF and it is the single biggest investment to support social and affordable rental housing in more than a decade.
The Albanese Government will deliver the Help to Buy scheme with state and territory governments to help thousands of Australians into home ownership.

The National Housing Infrastructure Facility (NHIF) has been expanded making up to $575 million available to invest in social and affordable rental homes, with projects already under construction as a result of this funding. The NHIF will also receive an additional $1 billion in federal funding to support more social housing.
Housing Australia's liability cap has been increased by $2 billion to provide lower cost and longer-term finance to community housing providers through the Affordable Housing Bond Aggregator.
We've delivered the largest increase to Commonwealth Rent Assistance in more than 30 years, with a 15 per cent increase in the maximum rate.
Tax incentives have been provided to encourage more build-to-rent developments to boost new supply in the private rental market.

Federal funding of $1.7 billion has been provided for a one-year extension of the National Housing and Homelessness Agreement with States and Territories, including a $67.5 million boost to homelessness funding over the next year.
Work to deliver on a new National Housing and Homelessness Plan is underway to identify the short, medium and long-term steps that can be taken to address housing issues in Australia.

More than 73,000 people have been helped into home ownership since the election of the Albanese Government through the Home Guarantee Scheme, including more than 9,000 through the Regional First Home Buyer Guarantee. The scheme has now been expanded significantly—changes will see friends, siblings, and other family members eligible for joint applications under the First Home Guarantee and the Regional First Home Buyer Guarantee.

We've also established an interim National Housing Supply and Affordability Council to provide expert advice and an evidence base on how Government can improve housing supply and affordability, and legislation has passed the Parliament to create the Council as a permanent independent body.

As you can see, the Albanese Government's ambitious housing reform agenda is designed to boost supply, increase housing affordability and make positive and practical differences for Australians planning to buy a home.
We are doing this to make sure more Australians have an affordable place to call home.
The Albanese Government has added to its broad housing agenda at every opportunity.
It's a plan we are proud of and after a decade of little action we are working hard to turn around the housing challenges in Australia today.
Once again thank you for taking the time to write to me. I hope the information provided is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing, Ms Collins (Petition No. EN5441)
Education Workforce
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 8 November 2022 regarding Petition Number 0544. Your correspondence was provided by the Standing Committee on Petitions Secretariat (the Secretariat) on 17 August 2023, following an earlier transmission issue. The Secretariat confirmed Standing Order 209(b) requirements to respond to a referred petition within 90 days has lapsed and there is no formal timeframe to respond to this petition.

The petition seeks to add a new category of education staff that specially accommodates disabled children in school, and for consideration of making it a requirement to have intervention/support staff in every school in Australia.

The Australian Government is committed to equitable, inclusive schooling for all students, including students with disability. All schools in Australia are required under the Disability Standards for Education 2005 to provide reasonable adjustments for students with disability so they can access and participate in education on the same basis as their peers.

Students with disability who require reasonable adjustments to fully participate in schooling are counted under the Nationally Consistent Collection of Data on School Students with Disability (NCCD). Teachers and other classroom professionals use their professional judgement to indicate the level of additional support a student is provided in the classroom. A formal diagnosis of disability is not required, and disability can be imputed.

To support the implementation of reasonable adjustments, the Government provides funding through the Schooling Resource Standard (SRS) student with disability loading. The loading calculation uses information reported in the NCCD. The Government is providing an estimated $27.4 billion in recurrent funding for schools in 2023 under the SRS funding arrangements, of which an estimated $3.1 billion is being provided under the student with disability loading. Schools and school systems have the flexibility to direct this funding to support their students.

All teachers must meet the requirements of the Australian Professional Standards for Teachers by designing and implementing teaching activities that support the participation and learning of students with disability. Teachers must also address relevant policy and legislative requirements.

The Government is also improving initial teacher education (ITE) to better prepare beginning teachers for the classroom and improve student outcomes. In July 2023, Education Ministers provided in-principle support to all 14 recommendations made by the Teacher Education Expert Panel (the Panel), and some initial actions were agreed. The first of these is adding core content to ITE course accreditation standards by the end of 2023 and ensuring core content is embedded in all ITE programs before the end of 2025.

One of the areas of core content identified by the Panel is responsive teaching and content that ensures teachers teach in ways that are culturally and contextually appropriate and responsive to the needs of diverse learners, including students with a disability. Submissions made to the Panel's discussion paper indicated broad support from stakeholders for the core content, including making explicit reference to supporting students with disability. Further information is available in the final report.

Several new resources have been released to support education providers in understanding and implementing their obligations towards students with disability. Co-designed resources have also been released to help students with disability and their families understand and exercise their rights. Further information about these resources is available on the Department of Education's website at www.education.gov.au/disability-standards-education-2005.

Australian schools utilise a variety of strategies to meet the needs of individual students with disability and to support adjustments, including different delivery approaches and engaging with support staff and allied health professionals where needed.

While the Australian Government plays a leadership role in education and provides substantial funding for schools, state and territory governments are responsible for the regulation, administration, and operation of schools. Accordingly, the petitioners may wish to raise their views with their state or territory Education Department. Contact information is enclosed.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Encl. Contact details for state and territory Education Departments
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare (Petition No. PN0544)
Energy
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 August 2023 regarding a petition on overhead powerlines (PN0564). I appreciate your work as the Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions and the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Australia's electricity grid needs to be strengthened and reconfigured to meet the demands of the rapidly changing electricity market it serves. One of our key programs that is strengthening the grid is the Rewiring the Nation program which provides low-cost finance for the urgent upgrade and expansion of Australia's electricity grid at lowest cost—to unlock new renewables, increase the security of the grid and drive down power prices.

The Rewiring the Nation program is guided by the Australian Energy Market Operator's (AEMO) Integrated System Plan (ISP) as the roadmap for Australia's future grid. The ISP's optimal development path identifies the necessary new transmission to connect new generation and storage, and efficiently deliver firmed renewable energy to consumers through the national electricity market.

Overhead transmission lines are reliable, efficient, and cost-effective means of transporting electricity across the country and are the best placed transmission infrastructure to empower Australia to meet its renewable energy goals. An overhead system is the most appropriate solution to allow the addition of future renewable energy generation plants to the grid. Undergrounding transmission lines is significantly more expensive and would place an unnecessary financial burden on energy users. Undergrounding also presents a number of technical issues. For example, undergrounding High Voltage Direct Current (HVDC) is technically feasible when directly connecting an energy generator to distribution, however many transmission projects in Australia require the ability to tap in and tap out additional generators along the project route.

Australia's new overhead transmission lines will be world-class, having undergone rigorous design and testing. All lines will meet the Australian and New Zealand electrical standards, which have been designed to minimise risk of fault and fire and ensure the safety of nearby communities. Transgrid presented evidence to the NSW Parliamentary inquiry into the feasibility of undergrounding the transmission infrastructure for renewable energy projects (the inquiry) that the current reliability expectation of the overhead AC network in New South Wales is 99.998 per cent. This is one example of the strict requirements imposed on network providers to ensure the stability and reliability of our electricity networks to minimise outages.

With the proper management and maintenance, transmission lines pose a very low risk of starting a fire. Electricity companies work directly with the Rural Fire Service in the ongoing management of lines and the prevention of bushfires. Their collaboration provides protection to communities and our natural environment in the unlikely event of a disaster. Bushfire risk was considered by the recent inquiry. Based on evidence provided by Transgrid and the Rural Fire Service, the inquiry found that overhead transmission lines do not pose a risk of igniting bushfires, and that the right procedures are in place to manage risk if bushfires are present.

Acknowledging the important role landholders and communities play in hosting critical transmission infrastructure, I encourage anyone directly affected to contact their relevant state or territory agency responsible for electricity transmission to find out more about compensation payments. For example:

The New South Wales Government has announced under the Strategic Benefit Payments Scheme, payments for a typical area of new transmission easement at a standard rate of $10,000 per km per year of transmission hosted for 20 years.
The Victorian Government has announced payments for a typical area of new transmission easement at a standard rate of $8,000 per km per year of transmission hosted for 25 years.

The Queensland Government, through its transmission company Powerlink, has announced the new SuperGrid Landholder Payment Framework, which will increase payments for landholders hosting new transmission infrastructure. The increase in payments is based on property-specific values and impacts as opposed to a flat rate. Powerlink will also be the first transmission company in Australia to offer payments to landholders with properties adjacent to new transmission infrastructure.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring the benefits of transmission projects are shared with the communities that host them. At the same time, it is important to note that compensation arrangements for landholders hosting or adjacent to transmissions lines is a state and territory responsibility.

Our government is committed to ensuring meaningful community engagement throughout the process of designing, planning, and implementing these vital transmission projects. The Australian Government has established a Community Engagement Review (the review) to bolster reforms in community engagement around renewable energy infrastructure upgrades and new developments.
